Document Title: Research and calculation of square stator teeth-yoke magnetic potential
Authors: Y. Huang; H. Wang
Author Affiliations: Institute of Electrical Engineering in Chinese Academy of Sciences, China; Institute of Electrical Engineering in Chinese Academy of Sciences, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: The square punching plate can improve the utilization ratio of silicon steel sheet, and it is widely used in the motors of home appliances. As one of the important parameters that dramatically affect the motor performance, the stator yoke magnetic potential plays a key role in the motor design process. This paper focuses on the stator yoke magnetic potential of a 15kW three-phase induction square motor, and the calculation method of square stator teeth-yoke magnetic potential is given. In this paper, the change rule of motor stator yoke magnetic potential with different square stator sizes are obtained, and it will provide reference for the design of square stator motor.

Document Title: Fault detection of bypass circuit of PV module — Detection technology of open circuit fault location
Authors: R. Kase; S. Nishikawa
Author Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, College of Science and Technology, Nihon University, Japan; Department of Electrical Engineering, College of Science and Technology, Nihon University, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: When bypass circuit of the PV module is opened and some solar cells are covered by a partial shadow, it is possible that the cells become hot spot by a reverse voltage. Moreover, the current detection methods have some problems that we have to measure the modules one by one, or the open position can't be identified in the string. The purpose of this research is to develop the detection technology for abnormal modules with open bypass circuit. We have developed the technique for detecting an open circuit position of bypass circuit in a string by observing the surface temperature change of the PV modules using DC power supply and infrared camera. In this paper, we report the principle and effect of detection technology we developed.
Author Keywords: PV module;DC power supply;IR camera;Bypass Circuit

Document Title: Frequency characteristics of the piezoelectric device for the floor-vibration generation
Authors: R. Nishikawa; N. Satoh
Author Affiliations: Department of Electrical, Electronics and Computer Engineering, Graduate School of Engineering, Chiba Institute of Technology, Japan; Department of Electrical, Electronics and Computer Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, Chiba Institute of Technology, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: In this study, we measured the frequency characteristics of three types of piezoelectric film in piezo-buzzer devices of different sizes. We compared the experimental and theoretical values of its resonant frequency, and investigated the size and thickness of the piezoelectric device that would be best suited to floor power generation. From these results, it was concluded that the piezoelectric devices having a resonant frequency in the range of 4.12 kHz to 5.67 kHz were desirable for use in this method of floor power-generation.

Document Title: The switching losses between Continuous and discontinuous space vector modulation drive a permanent magnet synchronous motor
Authors: J. Li; J. Zhang; P. Zhang; Y. Wang
Author Affiliations: The Institute of Electrical Engineering of the Chinese Academy of Sciences; University of Chinese Academy of Sciences; The Institute of Electrical Engineering of the Chinese Academy of Sciences; University of Chinese Academy of Sciences
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper describe two pulsewidth modulation, Continuous and discontinuous space vector modulation used for driving permanent magnet synchronous motors, the continuous space vector modulation (SVPWM) with lower harmonic which is widely used for motor control, but SVPWM generate more switching losses. The discontinuous space vector modulation (DPWM) with higher harmonic, but it has lower switching losses. Under the same switching losses condition, the switching frequency can be increased by 50% based on DPWM compared with SVPWM. To validate the conclusion, numerical simulation studies and experiments have been carried out and presented.

Document Title: A new design concept of PMSM for flux weakening operation
Authors: C. Li; T. Meng
Author Affiliations: School of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, Heilongjiang University, Harbin, China; School of Mechanical and Electrical Engineering, Heilongjiang University, Harbin, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: The field excitaion of permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) cannot be adjusted, and flux weakening for permanet magnet motor is one of the hotspot issues nowadays. A new design concept of PMSM for flux weakening was presented. D-axis inductance is smaller than q-axis inductance is regarded as common sense for PM motor, but a special permanent-magnet sheath changes it. The permanent-magent sheath in rotor makes a posibility of Ld>Lq for a PM motor. Flux-weakening priciple and control method of the PMSM with Ld>Lq are different from traditonal PMSM. The speed range above the rated speed is not only widened for the new PMSM, but also the torque below the rated speed is improved. The reason for difficulty of flux weakening for the traditional permanent magnet motor is analyized. The flux-weakening principle is formulated. The torque and flux-weakening charactersitics are anlylized. The results from simulation by finite element method verifies the validity of flux-weakening for the new PMSM with Ld>Lq.
Author Keywords: Permanent magnet synchronous motor;flux weakening;d-axis inductance and q-axis inductance;PM sheath
IEEE Terms: Magnetic flux;Permanent magnet motors;Inductance;Torque;Synchronous motors;Permanent magnets;Air gaps
INSPEC Controlled Terms: finite element analysis;magnetic flux;permanent magnet motors;rotors;synchronous motors;torque
INSPEC Non-Controlled Terms: field excitaion;permanent magnet synchronous motor;PMSM;flux weakening;D-axis inductance;q-axis inductance;permanent-magnet sheath;rotor;flux-weakening priciple;speed range;finite element method

Document Title: Study of high-speed SRM with amorphous steel sheet for EV
Authors: K. Ueta; K. Akatsu
Author Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Japan; Department of Electrical Engineering, Shibaura Institute of Technology, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Traction motors require high output power, high efficiency and downsizing. In order to achieve the requirements, this paper shows the high-speed SRM using the amorphous steel sheet (proposed SRM). As the result, a volume of the SRM is reduced by 53% compared with a conventional PMSM. Also 1% higher efficiency than it of the conventional SRM using 0.35mm electromagnetic steel sheet is obtained by the proposed SRM. In addition, the experimental efficiency for the proposed SRM is higher than analysis result for the SRM using electromagnetic steel sheet.

Author Affiliations: Institute of Electrical Engineering in Chinese Academy of Sciences, China; Institute of Electrical Engineering in Chinese Academy of Sciences, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Both the motor with cast copper rotor and variable frequency conversion motor has its own structure characteristics and design methods, and the combination of them will make the loss calculation complex, so it should be restudied. Based on the characteristics of motor with cast copper rotor and variable frequency conversion motor, this paper focuses on the loss calculation method of frequency conversion motor with cast copper rotor. The paper analyzes and calculates the stator copper loss, rotor copper loss, iron loss and stray loss successively. Finally, the experiment result is given out, and the loss calculation method is verified in directly.

Document Title: Research on electromagnetic and temperature fields of end region in evaporative cooling turbogenerator
Authors: Z. Liu; L. Ruan
Author Affiliations: Institute of Electrical Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, China; Institute of Electrical Engineering, Chinese Academy of Sciences, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: In evaporative cooling turbogenerator, all structures are immersed in evaporative cooling medium. At different positions inside the turbogenerator, evaporative cooling medium is in totally different boiling states, therefore, the heat transfer modes are not the same. According to pool boiling theory and narrow gap boiling theory, formulas of convective heat transfer coefficient are provided. Besides, in this paper, calculation model of end region in large turbogenerator is established based on the theory of electromagnetic field. By solving the transient magnetic field in end region, three-dimensional transient electro-magnetic field distribution, eddy current loss and iron loss are obtained. Using the eddy current loss and iron loss gained from numerical calculation of electro-magnetic fields as heat source, combined with theories of fluid mechanics and heat transfer, temperature distribution of each structure in end region is obtained.
Author Keywords: Turbogenerator;End region;Evaporative cooling;Simulation;Temperature distribution
IEEE Terms: Heat transfer;Cooling;Stator cores;Turbogenerators;Magnetic flux leakage;Magnetic shielding;Eddy currents

Document Title: Design and analysis of a hybrid permanent magnet variable-flux flux-intensifying machine
Authors: Y. Lu; J. Li; R. Qu; A. Sun
Author Affiliations: State Key Laboratory of Advanced Electromagnetic Engineering and Technology, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, China; State Key Laboratory of Advanced Electromagnetic Engineering and Technology, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, China; State Key Laboratory of Advanced Electromagnetic Engineering and Technology, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, China; State Key Laboratory of Advanced Electromagnetic Engineering and Technology, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Variable flux machines utilizing low coercive-force magnet material Alnico have attracted many attentions due to its features of variable flux controllability which can obtain a wide speed range and high efficiency at the entire speed range. However, since the remnant magnetism of Alnico is always lower than rear-earth magnets, leading to a lower torque output. A hybrid permanent magnet variable-flux flux-intensifying machine (HVFI-IPM) which NdFeB and Alnico are both tangential magnetized is first proposed to improve torque density. The details design of this machine is investigated and validated by finite element analysis (FEA). Besides, magnetization performance is also studied. In addition, the torque-speed envelopes and efficiency maps of different magnetization states are calculated and conclude that this machine can achieve high efficiency at the entire torque-speed range.

Document Title: Experimental evaluation of iron loss minimization in automotive traction drives by increased disturbance rejection and precise flux control
Authors: M. Saur; D. Gaona; J. Zdravkovic; F. Hentschel; R. D. Lorenz; D. Gerling
Author Affiliations: Universität der Bundeswehr München; University of Oviedo, EMMC STEPS Consortium; University of Oviedo, EMMC STEPS Consortium; Universität der Bundeswehr München; University of Wisconsin-Madison; Universität der Bundeswehr München
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Iron losses predominate in automotive traction applications at partial load and thus significantly in driving cycles. In this work, iron losses and overall drive losses of saturated salient pole synchronous machines are minimized by optimal control of flux linkage, in magnitude and waveform. Loss minimizing flux magnitude is calculated in real-time including copper-, inverter- and iron losses. By applying deadbeat-direct torque and flux control (DB-DTFC), flux linkage including harmonics is observed with a Gopinath observer and precisely closed-loop controlled with a bandwidth of 1400Hz. Increased disturbance rejection, as compared to current vector control (CVC), is achieved via simulation and experiment. Minimization of harmonics in current and reduction of total loss are measured on a 5.5kW synchronous reluctance machine (SynRM) testbench.
Author Keywords: automotive traction application;deadbeat-direct torque and flux control (DB-DTFC);flux and current harmonics;loss minimizing control (LMC)

Authors: Y. Ling; Z. Zhao; L. Yuan; K. Chen
Author Affiliations: State Key Laboratory of Power System, Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua Univ., Beijing, China; State Key Laboratory of Power System, Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua Univ., Beijing, China; State Key Laboratory of Power System, Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua Univ., Beijing, China; State Key Laboratory of Power System, Dept. of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua Univ., Beijing, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: In two-level PWM rectifiers, two common control strategies are respectively VOC (Voltage Oriented Control) and DPC (Direct Power Control). In high power applications, the converter performance may suffer seriously from the non-ideal characteristics of the sampling and control system. The effects of the non-ideal characteristics will be analyzed in this paper for classic VOC, DPC and PDPC (Predictive Direct Power Control). These effects are also verified by the corresponding simulations. In the end, some methods are proposed to suppress and eliminate the non-ideal effects.

Document Title: Performance evaluation of thin electrical steels applied to interior permanent magnet motor
Authors: T. A. Huynh; M. Hsieh
Author Affiliations: Department of Systems and Naval Mechatronic Engineering, National Cheng Kung University, Taiwan; Department of Systems and Naval Mechatronic Engineering, National Cheng Kung University, Taiwan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This work investigates the impact of thin electrical steel laminations on the performance of interior permanent magnet (IPM) motors for electric vehicle traction. Three different electrical steel grades are used in an IPM motor design and the performance is evaluated by simulation. It is found that thin laminations can improve the efficiency of the IPM motor but the output torque could be slightly reduced due to lower saturation flux density. Therefore, direct replacement of core materials for the same motor design may not be suitable. This paper presents the considerations for design of IPM motors using thin laminations. The motor performance is evaluated in terms of torque, efficiency and constant power speed range. A method is then proposed for design of high performance IPM motors using thin laminations. Experimental studies are conducted to validate the simulation and design.
Author Keywords: Traction motor;IPM motor;thin lamination;field weakening control

Document Title: Design of a novel consequent-pole interior PM motor for applying to refrigerant compressor
Authors: M. Chui; J. Chiang; Z. Gaing; C. Lin
Author Affiliations: New Widetech Company, New Taipei City 235, Taiwan; New Widetech Company, New Taipei City 235, Taiwan; Department of Electrical Engineering, Kao-Yuan University, Kaohsiung City 821, Taiwan; New Widetech Company, New Taipei City 235, Taiwan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: In this study, a novel, cost-effective consequent-pole interior permanent-magnet motor is designed to be applied in inverter-based air-conditioner refrigerant compressor. As the proposed motor has lesser magnetic usage, its performance variations based on four geometric parameters were studied. Moreover, a multi-target fuzzy-inference Taguchi method is employed to determine the best parameters combination required in order to achieve the quality goals of lower cogging torque and higher efficiency. Experimental results have shown that this proposed cost-effective motor can exhibit excellent performance characteristics and has the potential to become a driving motor of refrigerant compressors.

Document Title: The influence of the induction motor rotor geometry on the higher harmonic index of the zero-sequence current
Authors: K. N. Gyftakis; J. A. Antonino-Daviu; J. C. Kappatou
Author Affiliations: Coventry University, EC Building, Gulson Road, Coventry, CV12JH, UK; Universidad Politécnica de Valencia, Instituto Tecnologico de la Energia, Camino de Vera s/n, 46022, Valencia, Spain; University of Patras, Electrical and Computer Engineering Dept., Rion, 26500, Greece
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Lately, a new diagnostic mean has been introduced for reliable fault diagnosis in delta-connected induction motors. This diagnostic mean is the zero-sequence current frequency spectrum. Since this diagnostic mean successfully answers to a variety of reliability demands, a thorough investigation of its harmonic index has to be performed as a function of the rotor geometry. In this work, FEM sinulations have been performed for motors of different rotor slot numbers and the zero-sequence current spectra are studied with the application of the FFT. Finally, experimental testing is applied to verify the simulations results.

Document Title: Dynamic behavior of a medium-voltage N-channel SiC-IGBT with ultra-fast switching performance of 300 kV/as
Authors: K. Koseki; Y. Yonezawa; T. Mizushima; S. Matsunaga; Y. Iizuka; H. Yamaguchi
Author Affiliations: Advanced Power Electronics Research Center, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba Central 2, 1-1-1 Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305-8568, Japan; Advanced Power Electronics Research Center, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba Central 2, 1-1-1 Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305-8568, Japan; Advanced Power Electronics Research Center, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba Central 2, 1-1-1 Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305-8568, Japan; Advanced Power Electronics Research Center, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba Central 2, 1-1-1 Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305-8568, Japan; Corporate R&D Headquarters, Fuji Electric Co. Ltd., 1 Fujimachi, Hino, Tokyo 191-8502, Japan; Advanced Power Electronics Research Center, National Institute of Advanced Industrial Science and Technology, Tsukuba Central 2, 1-1-1 Umezono, Tsukuba, Ibaraki 305-8568, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: N-channel Silicon Carbide Insulated Gate Bipolar Transistor (SiC-IGBT) with reverse blocking voltage of 16 kV was developed on 4H-SiC carbon face. The double-pulse test with an inductive load has been conducted to investigate dynamic behavior with DC-bus voltage of 5 kV. It is found that a separation of current-path for the gate driving circuit and the main circuit is essential to secure stable operation. The newly developed power module with isolated gate driving circuit from the main circuit, ultra-fast switching speed of 303 kV/as is successfully accomplished. Moreover, extremely low switching loss of 3mJ for turn-on and 3.6 mJ for turn-off, respectively are measured. Thus, the superiority of fastening the switching speed in reduction of switching loss was experimentally confirmed.

Document Title: Study of single-stage PFC DCM flyback converter for a short arc lamp
Authors: K. R. Ryu; W. M. Kim; J. D. La
Author Affiliations: Dept. of R&D Center, Shin Han EPS Co., Ltd., Korea; Dept. of R&D Center, Shin Han EPS Co., Ltd., Korea; Dept. of Electrical Information, Inha Technical College, Korea
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Short arc lamps are now widely utilized as illumination sources for a large number of investigations in wide-field fluorescence microscopy. Among many power converters for the lamp, the flyback converter is chosen by many converter designers due to high power density, structural simplicity, and miniaturization. Also, an electrolytic capacitor is generally chosen for the stabilization of the DC voltage because of having the large capacitance and the low price. However, the disadvantages are the short expected life time and 120Hz ripple currents on the converter output node. In this paper, a single-stage PFC DCM flyback is proposed. Also, for the long lifetime of the converter, the polyester film capacitor with the small capacitance is substituted for the electrolytic capacitor on the output node and an LC resonant filter is added to damp 120Hz ripple current. The proposed converter is verified through the simulation and the experimental works.
Author Keywords: Electrolytic capacitorless;single-stage PFC DCM flyback converter;Short arc lamp;LED lamp

Abstract: This paper aims to study characteristics of interturn fault in a single-phase transformer using an experimental setup. Conventional dry-type single-phase transformer rated of 15 kVA and voltage of 220/440 V has been used in the experiment. The winding of transformer was separated as three sub-coils and to evaluate characteristics of interturn fault, the short-circuit between the sub-coil of high voltage side has been performed as the interturn fault. The obtained results show that the behavior of the winding fault is important for developing a fault detection scheme.

Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: In this paper, we proposed a novel resistor free ZCD control method for critical conduction mode PFC to improve the problem raised from the existence of the current sensing resistor and the conventional studies without the current sensing resistor. Characteristics of the proposed topology at steady-state was described, and the feasible optimal design process was also reported with simulations and equations. The proposed control circuit applied prototype was produced, and two outcomes were drawn. First, the switching frequency achieved its target on-time in the low voltage range of the rectified sine wave since on-time of the proposed control circuit was not fixed. This resulted high power factor operation by transforming of the current wave which is equivalent to the input voltage. Secondly, non-use of the current sensing resistor led the power factor to improve as well as increasing the power conversion efficiency. Consequently, it was found that the novel critical conduction mode PFC control circuit without current sensing resistor was valid at low output load.

Abstract: The proposed paper presents the fabrication and the modeling of magnetic membranes composed of Fe<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> or NdFeB powder, and which could be polarized in order to create soft magnets. In this paper, two hyperelastic models (Yeoh and Gent) are chosen to describe the mechanical behaviour of such membrane. For different ratio mass of powder and several thicknesses of membranes, a tensile test is achieved in order to evaluate the parameters of each model. This step allows fitting models curves with measurement curve and evaluate the relative error between each model and measurement. Thus, the best model can be determinate. An implementation of these parameters into FEM software allows computing the displacement of the membrane in function of the applied pressure. A simple setup constituted of the air chamber, the laser and the membrane support leads to a measure of the membrane displacement in the real case. The low relative error of 20% validates the proposed approach.

Author Affiliations: Department of Engineering, University of Applied Sciences Kaiserslautern, Germany; Department of Engineering, University of Applied Sciences Kaiserslautern, Germany; Department of Mechatronics, KSB Aktiengesellschaft, Germany; Department of Mechatronics, KSB Aktiengesellschaft, Germany
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: To date, the induction motor (IM) and increasingly the synchronous reluctance motor (SynRM) are well established as energy efficient standard motors in general applications as pumping systems or compressors. However, for many applications with special requirements it is necessary to leave the common motor design. One consequence may be the enlargement of the motor air gap, e.g. in slim long motors or in motors with encapsulated rotor. An enlarged air gap is highly problematic for the torque density of both motor types, which leads to the use of resource critical rare earth permanent magnet motors in many applications. This paper first discusses the need of new motor design with enlarged air gap for different applications. After that the influence of the air gap width on the performance of SynRM is shown analytically and in a parameter study based on numerical finite element method (FEM). Finally, a particularly resource efficient motor design to compensate the performance losses is presented and discussed.

Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Field-oriented control (FOC) is a preferred control method for induction motors. The purpose of FOC is to guarantee perfect dynamic and steady performance of induction motors, but there is cross-coupling between dq current components, which impairs the characteristics of response. Therefore, a decoupled current control strategy using internal model based on active disturbance rejection control (ADRC) is proposed. The internal model control (IMC) is used to control an ideal motor decoupled model, which is directly related to the system dynamic response performance. The ADRC is used to estimate and compensate the disturbances so that it reduces the reliance of IMC on the time constant of filter when the model mismatches. The proposed method has great contribution to the robustness of parameter uncertainties and disturbances. The experimental results indicate that the robustness of the proposed optimal design method for IMC is better than the conventional IMC when the disturbances occur and the model mismatches, and the method is feasible and effective.

Abstract: Interior permanent magnet synchronous motors (IPMSMs) are widely utilized as traction motors. The permanent magnets (PMs) used in IPMSMs are an important factor; thus, high-coercivity PMs with lesser rare-earth elements are in development. This paper investigates the performance of IPMSMs typically used in automotive applications that were modified to contain a novel magnet model (NMM). Rotor models with two PM arrangements, a V-shaped single-layered PM structure (Type 1V) and a double-layered PM structure (Type 2D), were considered in this study. This paper discusses the characteristics of the analysis models based on the results of two-dimensional finite element analysis. The maximum torques of Types 1V and 2D with the NMMs were approximately the same. In addition, the loss of Type 2D with the NMM was lower than that of Type 1V with the NMM at two evaluation points and under two driving schedules. Therefore, Type 2D was proved to be suitable for use with NMMs.

Document Title: Advanced multi-functional model predictive control for three-phase AC/DC converters
Authors: X. Shi; J. Zhu; D. Dah-Chuan Lu; L. Li
Author Affiliations: School of Electrical, Mechanical and Mechatronic Systems, University of Technology, Sydney, Australia; School of Electrical, Mechanical and Mechatronic Systems, University of Technology, Sydney, Australia; School of Electrical, Mechanical and Mechatronic Systems, University of Technology, Sydney, Australia; School of Electrical, Mechanical and Mechatronic Systems, University of Technology, Sydney, Australia
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: With the conventional model predictive control (MPC) based direct power control of three-phase AC/DC converters, the active and reactive powers can be simultaneously controlled by a single cost function. A change in parameters of either the active or reactive power within the cost function will affect the other, leading to poor dynamic performance of transient response. Besides, the steady state performance of the conventional MPC is affected by one-step-delay of digital implementation. This paper proposes an advanced multi-functional MPC of three-phase full-bridge AC/DC converter for high power applications. It has multiple functions such as one-step-delay compensation, power ripple reduction, switching frequency reduction, and dynamic mutual influence elimination. Using the proposed modified cost function, both the steady state and dynamic performances of the converter can be improved. Finally, the simulation results are reported to validate the advancement of the proposed control strategy in comparison with other control methods.

Authors: Z. Xu; K. Jeong; D. Lee; J. Ahn

Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: In this paper, a novel 12/8 segmental rotor type switched reluctance motor (SRM) is proposed for vehicle cooling fan application. Unlike conventional structures, the stator of the proposed structure is constructed with two special stator poles in which the exciting and auxiliary poles are designed exclusively. The rotor is constructed from a series of discrete segments, each of which is embedded in the nonmagnetic isolator. And the windings are only wound on the exciting stator poles. These configurations lead to short flux paths and no flux reversal in the stator of the proposed SRM. Hence, compared with conventional SRMs, the proposed structure may increase the electric utilization and reduce magneto-motive force (MMF) requirement. To verify the proposed structure, the prototype of the proposed SRM is designed and manufactured. The performance of the proposed motor is evaluated and compared with a conventional 12/8 SRM. Finally, both the static and dynamic performances of the two motors are presented and compared.

Authors: N. Kurita; T. Ishikawa; H. Kamata
Author Affiliations: Division of Electronics and Informatics, Gunma University, 1-5-1 Tenjin, Kiryu, Gunma, 376-8515, Japan; Division of Electronics and Informatics, Gunma University, 1-5-1 Tenjin, Kiryu, Gunma, 376-8515, Japan; Division of Electronics and Informatics, Gunma University, 1-5-1 Tenjin, Kiryu, Gunma, 376-8515, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: A magnetically levitated motor can realize non-contact support of a rotor using magnetic force. Therefore, it has many advantages over conventional mechanical bearings. In order to accomplish complete magnetic levitation of the rotor, it is necessary to control five degrees of freedom actively. However, this gives rise to major issues such as complicated control system and associated electronics, resulting in enlarged equipment size. The proposed magnetic levitated motor uses a radial self-bearing motor to control both radial translation motion and rotation, and an axial magnetic bearing to control both axial translation and tilt motion. Moreover, stators were installed on the inner side of the rotor, such that the flux path of the axial magnetic bearing and radial self-bearing motor are partially-shared. Therefore, the proposed magnetic levitated motor is small, while achieving five degrees of freedom active control. The prototype device was designed using FEM. According to this analysis, the device had sufficient magnetic force to control the rotor within a designed airgap of ±1.8 mm.

Abstract: For the purpose of energy saving, a fuel cell train is attracting public attention in the railway field. The fuel cell train is driven by fuel cell and battery hybrid power, and stores energy in the form of hydrogen. The required amount of these power and energy are depending on the conditions of line alignments such as a gradient, a running distance. Therefore, in this study, we carried out energy simulation of the fuel cell train while changing the above conditions, and examined a tendency of the train mass increase. As a result, it was found out that a fuel cell train has an advantage in system mass compared with a battery train when a gradient becomes larger and a running distance gets longer.

Authors: F. Qi; I. Ralev; A. Klein-Hessling; R. W. De Doncker
Author Affiliations: Institute for Power Electronics and Electrical Drives, RWTH Aachen University, Jaegerstr. 17-19, 52066 Aachen, Germany; Institute for Power Electronics and Electrical Drives, RWTH Aachen University, Jaegerstr. 17-19, 52066 Aachen, Germany; Institute for Power Electronics and Electrical Drives, RWTH Aachen University, Jaegerstr. 17-19, 52066 Aachen, Germany; Institute for Power Electronics and Electrical Drives, RWTH Aachen University, Jaegerstr. 17-19, 52066 Aachen, Germany
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: The critical components in electric machines must be protected against overheating. Overheating shortens the life span of the machine and causes machine failure in extreme cases. This paper presents an online temperature estimator for an automotive switched reluctance machine based on a space-resolved lumped parameter thermal network. The losses are calculated online using a pre-measured loss map and a set of loss-splitting functions. The effects of the non-ideal thermal sensors are taken into account. The parameters of the temperature estimator are determined by means of a global parameter identification procedure. The results given by this model show a temperature estimation error less than 7 °C over the full speed and torque range. The ability to accurately predict hot-spot temperature provides evidence for the use of advanced thermal protection and allows for an optimized utilization of switched reluctance machines.

Document Title: A comparison of axial field topologies employing SMC for traction applications
Authors: N. J. Stannard; J. G. Washington; G. J. Atkinson
Author Affiliations: School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Merz Court, Newcastle University, Newcastle-upon-Tyne, UK; Höganäs AB, SE-263 83 Höganäs, Sweden; School of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Merz Court, Newcastle University, Newcastle-upon-Tyne, UK
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper compares three high aspect ratio axial field topologies for traction applications employing soft magnetic composite (SMC). The paper examines the following topologies using finite element (FE) method: a torus, a yokeless and segmented armature (YASA), and a single-sided configuration. All the machines are designed to the same specification for a light electric vehicle, and the FE simulations are benchmarked against prototype motors tested in the laboratory. The topologies are compared in terms of torque density, efficiency, manufacturability, and cost, and benchmarked against a traditional laminated radial flux machine. The paper discusses several important aspects of designing axial flux machines using SMC, and shows that the YASA topology has the best overall performance due to its shorter iron circuit. The YASA machine is significantly more compact than rival designs and due to the lower material usage, is also cheaper to manufacture despite the higher cost of SMC compared to laminations.

Document Title: Noise suppression strategy for sensorless electromagnetic levitation using current-ripple measurement method with extended operational range of duty ratio
Authors: S. Ahmed; T. Koseki
Author Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering and Information Systems, The University of Tokyo, Japan; Department of Electrical Engineering and Information Systems, The University of Tokyo, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper demonstrates, experimentally, sensorless magnetic levitation for industrial translational motion applications. The sensorless method used is current-ripple slope measurement which includes exciting an electromagnetic coil by a switching voltage and measuring its response. The resulting current has a triangular shaped waveform (current-ripple). Using high speed samplers, the current-ripple is sampled multiple times and the derivative (slope) of rising and falling current is estimated using least squares method. It is then used to calculate inductance and consequently the air gap. Our method allows estimation without limiting duty ratio range, which was a serious problem in previous research. Furthermore, since current sensor noise appears within air gap signal, we also propose a noise suppression strategy by combining state observer to the proposed method to achieve an acceptable signal to noise ratio and consequently, a stable suspension.

Abstract: We have proposed the sensorless model control based on the static model equation of the dc-dc converter that is able to change the bias value corresponding to changes of the load current, the input voltage and output voltage. The sensorless model control can regulate the output voltage. On the other hand, the transient response of output voltage is not improved. Therefore, an improvement of the transient response is carried out by adding the transient improvement function which changes a bias value drastically for a short time at the start of the transient state. The purpose of this paper is to indicate the parameter setting of the transient improvement function that improves the transient response by the simulation analysis under changing the circuit condition.

Document Title: AC/DC converter with indirect matrix converter using a novel snubber configuration
Authors: S. Ono; H. Funato; J. Haruna
Author Affiliations: Utsunomiya University, 7-1-2 Yoto Utsunomiya Tochigi, Japan; Utsunomiya University, 7-1-2 Yoto Utsunomiya Tochigi, Japan; Utsunomiya University, 7-1-2 Yoto Utsunomiya Tochigi, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper proposes AC/DC converter with high frequency isolation. The proposed converter employs an indirect matrix converter (IMC) to convert three phase AC to high frequency AC using a novel snubber configuration and control suitable for implementation using 6-in-1 module. In an IMC, a snubber circuit is required instead of electrolyte capacitor in order to absorb energy of leakage inductor of transformers. In addition, both input and output have to be controlled simultaneously. In this paper, a novel snubber configuration is proposed suitable for implementation with 6-in-1 module. Control scheme for the proposed circuit is also explained in order to realize reliable and high efficient converter.

Abstract: This paper presents a hybrid energy-harvesting integrated chip (IC), which is suitable for the Internet of Things and portable devices. The proposed IC was designed for the harvesting of energy from ambient light as well as vibrations in the environment. A constant voltage method is used to balance power conversion efficiency against the complexity of the circuit used to process lighting energy. Abstract: Interior permanent magnet synchronous motors (IPMSMs) are used in various applications. It is desirable to reduce the amount of Dy used in the rare-earth magnets contained in IPMSMs, but Dy-free magnets can easily be irreversibly demagnetized, leading to the performance degradation of IPMSMs. Thus, this study investigates the influence of the shape of the demagnetized area in a permanent magnet on the characteristics of the IPMSM. The shape of the demagnetized area, which has little influence on the IPMSM characteristics, was determined. In addition, rotor structures that yield a suitable demagnetized area shape are proposed for suppressing the performance degradation of the IPMSM, and their characteristics were compared with those of the basic model.

Abstract: The double-sided slotted permanent magnet synchronous linear motor (PMSLM) has the advantages of high thrust density and high power factor. This paper adopted the structure of tooth-shifted double sides and obtained the influence law on thrust characteristic under different tooth-shifted distance by using finite element simulation. It also compared tooth-shifting and pole-shifting. Combining the orthogonal optimization algorithm, multiple parameters of the slot were optimized to achieve high thrust density. In order to suppress thrust ripple effectively, the ladder end tooth was applied as well. On the secondary, the surface-inserted non-magnetic secondary structure was adopted with non-magnetic materials. These improvements not only suppressed thrust ripple effectively but also increased the average thrust. A small-scale prototype of double-sided PMSLM was developed to verify the theory and simulation calculation related.

Abstract: Interior permanent magnet synchronous motors (IPMSMs) are widely used in many applications because of their higher performance. In recent years, there has been an increasing interest in motor design technologies that can realize required specifications. Therefore, it is important to shorten the design period and generalize the design method. In the present paper, the design period is shortened using the coarse-mesh finite element method (FEM). The present paper demonstrates the usefulness of a genetic algorithm (GA) coupled with the coarse-mesh FEM for an IPMSM structure having a large high-efficiency operation area. Abstract: Interior permanent-magnet synchronous motors (IPMSMs) commonly contain sintered rare-earth magnets, the use of which is disadvantageous and should be reduced. As a solution for this problem, the use of bonded rare-earth magnets in IPMSMs was investigated in this study. The purpose of this study was to design an IPMSM containing bonded magnets that can be adopted as a substitute for conventional IPMSMs containing sintered magnets. An omega-shaped magnet arrangement was proposed to improve the torque characteristics of the bonded-magnet IPMSM. In this paper, the characteristics of IPMSMs containing sintered and bonded magnets with different magnet arrangements were investigated and compared. The characteristics of the IPMSMs with omega-shaped arrangements were found to be nearly equivalent to or better than those of the conventional IPMSM.

Abstract: This paper presents an advanced finite control set model predictive control (FCS-MPC) method, to reduce current ripple of the single-phase grid-tied inverters. Abstract: This paper describes the frequency analysis method of the conducted noise in AC/DC converter using SiC-MOSFETs on the basis of the leakage current by converter switching. The error of the experimental and simulation result of the disturbance voltage is 10 dBμV. Furthermore, the simulation result can be closely simulated including resonance points. This paper presents the relatively simple modeling method in the way impedance characteristics of EMI filters are constructed by lumped parameter circuits. The experimental result with the modeled filter shows the attenuation tendency like the simulation result. In addition, the experimental result with the filter can be reduced in the whole frequency region and reduced by maximum 20 dBμV in comparison to the result without the filter. Effectiveness is verified by several simulation and modeling results.

Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper proposed an integrated hall magnetic encoder error correction method. In order to eliminate the steady-state error caused by installation errors and so on, this paper proposed three-phase zero and sine symmetric reconstruction. The sum of three-phase hall signal could be constant zero through zero reconstruction. In sine symmetric reconstruction method, transform three-phase hall signal into two-phase orthogonal static coordinate to make sinusoidal orthogonal reconstruction. Then Symmetrical three-phase sinusoidal signal could be obtained using Clark transform. In order to solve dynamic error in temperature drift, this paper proposed a mapping projection method. This algorithm calculates real-time signal amplitude to get temperature drift coefficient. After standardize actual signal using this proportion factor, motor position angle can be received by querying standard table. The proposed solution can solve position angle constant and jump problem near the endpoint of angle section. Moreover, it has simple realization and high response speed. The simulation and experiments were carried out to prove the performance and validity.

Abstract: This paper proposes a mathematical model representing the maximum torque per ampere curve of a permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) and a synchronous reluctance motor (SynRM) in the M-T frame synchronized with the stator flux linkage vector. The proposed model gives the relationship between the stator flux linkage and the armature current. It has advantages such as simple calculation and suitable expression for direct torque control based PMSM drives. Two types of PMSMs, an interior PMSM and a surface PMSM (SPMSM), and SynRM are evaluated using finite element analysis. The proposed model of the SPMSM is evaluated by experiment. The validity, including the overload range, is confirmed in this study.

Abstract: This paper discussed the regulation characteristics of boundary conduction mode PFC converter with a novel zero-crossing point detector. In the conventional method, the zero-crossing point is detected by observing the change of inductor voltage. The detection of zero-crossing point is delayed due to the effect of parasitic capacitors in the main components of PFC converter. The proposed detector can effectively reduce the detection delay time and make the PFC converter to operate under boundary conduction mode in more accuracy. Simulation results show that significantly improved regulation characteristics can be obtained with the proposed method.

Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: The lack of feedback on a tactile device can be improved by using piezoelectric actuators. According to the acoustic time reversal mirror principles, the piezoelectric actuators can, first, record impulse excitation signals from different positions and later on, regenerate the impulse at desired positions by reversing the recorded signals. A mathematical model with damping effect is presented to explain the phenomenon. A beam prototype has been made to validate the model and to prove the effectiveness to create a sufficient amplitude which meets the requirement for touch feedback. The influence of the damping ratio has also been carefully examined to optimise the reverse signal duration window.

Document Title: Demagnetization analysis of ferrite magnet motor based on reluctance network analysis
Authors: D. Momma; Y. Yoshida; K. Tajima
Author Affiliations: Graduate School of Engineering and Resource Science, Akita University, 1-1, Tegata Gakuen-machi, Akita, Japan; Graduate School of Engineering Science, Akita University, 1-1, Tegata Gakuen-machi, Akita, Japan; Graduate School of Engineering Science, Akita University, 1-1, Tegata Gakuen-machi, Akita, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper presents a method for demagnetization analysis of ferrite magnet motor based on reluctance network analysis (RNA). First, to verify the accuracy of the proposed method, the calculated results are compared to experimental results by using experimental model. Next, an RNA model of a surface permanent magnet (SPM) motor considering demagnetization of the rotor magnets is presented. Using the proposed RNA model, the torque of the SPM motor is compared between before and after demagnetization.
Author Keywords: ferrite magnet;demagnetization analysis;reluctance network analysis (RNA);surface permanent magnet (SPM) motor

Document Title: A novel rotor structure of IPMSM with rare earth and ferrite magnets
Authors: T. Masuko; I. Miki
Author Affiliations: School of Science and Technology, Meiji University, 1-1-1 Higashimita, Tama-ku Kawasaki, 214-8571, Japan; School of Science and Technology, Meiji University, 1-1-1 Higashimita, Tama-ku Kawasaki, 214-8571, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper presents a novel rotor structure of interior permanent magnet synchronous motor (IPMSM) using rare earth and ferrite magnets for some concerns about future supplies of materials. In this IPMSM, the total volume of Nd-Fe-B magnets can be reduced by 58 % compared with a basic IPMSM model. We analyzed motor characteristics such as the torque, efficiency, stress in the rotor, and demagnetization of permanent magnets by the three-dimensional finite element method (3D-FEM). According to simulation results, the torque and efficiency in the proposed IPMSM are better than those of the basic IPMSM model.
Author Keywords: Interior permanent magnet synchronous motor;Rare earth magnet;Ferrite magnet;Novel rotor structure
IEEE Terms: Magnetic flux;Magnetic cores;Magnetomechanical effects;Perpendicular magnetic anisotropy;Ferrites;Torque

Document Title: Mathematical model considering air gap space harmonics in IPMSM
Authors: A. Maema; S. Shimomura; M. Kono
Author Affiliations: Shibaura Institute of Technology, 3-7-5Toyosu Koto-ku Tokyo, Japan; Shibaura Institute of Technology, 3-7-5Toyosu Koto-ku Tokyo, Japan; DAIKIN INDUSTRIES, LTD. 1-1, Nishi-Hitotsuya, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Mathematical models considering cross-magnetization due to magnetic saturation in IPMSMs have been reported by many researchers. However, their models do not strictly consider space harmonics in armature current magnetomotive force (MMF), rotor magnet MMF and air gap permeance. Therefore, we propose a new strict mathematical model. The full paper will elaborate on the model and show validation results by finite element analysis simulation.

Document Title: Impact of the inverter DC bus voltage on the core losses of a permanent magnet synchronous motor at constant speed
Authors: N. Denis; Y. Wu; K. Fujisaki
Author Affiliations: Toyota Technological Institute, 2-12-1 Hisakata, Tenpaku Ward, 468-8511, Nagoya, Japan; Toyota Technological Institute, 2-12-1 Hisakata, Tenpaku Ward, 468-8511, Nagoya, Japan; Toyota Technological Institute, 2-12-1 Hisakata, Tenpaku Ward, 468-8511, Nagoya, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: In this paper, the impact of the DC bus voltage on the core losses of a permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) fed by a pulse-width modulation inverter is evaluated. Under constant speed operation, the modulation index decreases when the DC bus voltage increases. This modifies the harmonic content of the PMSM input voltage and then affects the motor core losses. The experimental results show that, for the conditions considered in this paper, the core losses are 1.8 times larger at the lowest modulation index than at the highest one.
Author Keywords: Core losses;Magnetic material;Permanent magnet synchronous motor;Voltage source inverter

Document Title: Design and analysis of permanent magnet motor without shoes of stator teeth considering cogging torque reduction
Authors: R. Kim; J. Seo; S. Rhyu
Author Affiliations: Korea Electronics Technology Institute, 203-101 #388, Songnaedae-ro, Wonmi-gu, Bucheon, Korea; Korea Electronics Technology Institute, 203-101 #388, Songnaedae-ro, Wonmi-gu, Bucheon, Korea; Korea Electronics Technology Institute, 203-101 #388, Songnaedae-ro, Wonmi-gu, Bucheon, Korea
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: In this paper, the permanent magnet motor without shoes of stator teeth was designed. In case of a shoeless motor, it is very easy to manufacture a stator with coil windings. It has, however, high cogging torque and torque ripples generally. The proposed model in this paper was designed considering cogging torque characteristic. The finite element analysis was performed to evaluate the effect of reducing cogging torque and improving motor operating performance by comparing the proposed no-shoe model with original model.

Document Title: Nanocrystalline soft magnetic material applied to IPMSM evaluated by FEM calculation
Authors: M. Inoue; S. Odawara; K. Fujisaki
Author Affiliations: Hitachi Metals. Ltd, Shimane, Japan; Toyota Technological Institute, Aichi, Japan; Toyota Technological Institute, Aichi, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: To achieve a high efficiency motor, core loss reduction is shown by FEM calculation in replacing conventional steel plate with Fe-based amorphous alloy and nanocrystalline soft magnetic material. Especially, 98% core loss reduction is found when nanocrystalline soft magnetic material and bonded NdFeB permanent magnet are applied to IPMSM. The reduced core loss is expected to be a few percentages of the other components of motor losses as cupper loss and mechanical loss.

Document Title: FPGA based direct measurement of PWM voltage and inverter disturbance
Authors: J. Xia; W. Sun; Y. Yin; Z. Xing; X. Yuan
Author Affiliations: State Key Laboratory of Automotive Simulation and Control, Jilin University, Changchun, P.R. China; State Key Laboratory of Automotive Simulation and Control, Jilin University, Changchun, P.R. China; State Key Laboratory of Automotive Simulation and Control, Jilin University, Changchun, P.R. China; State Key Laboratory of Automotive Simulation and Control, Jilin University, Changchun, P.R. China; State Key Laboratory of Automotive Simulation and Control, Jilin University, Changchun, P.R. China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Inverter disturbance has been widely discussed to improve the performance of AC motor control, with the very high nonlinearity and uncertainty of power electronic devices, it is still very difficult to be estimated and compensated accurately; therefore, the performances of most AC motor observers are affected by the inaccurate terminal voltage estimation. In this paper, the principle of PWM (pulse width modulation) is discussed to better understand the definition of inverter disturbance. Based on high speed ADC and FPGA, a direct measurement for accurately obtaining the inverter output voltage and inverter disturbance online is proposed. Because physical models and parameters are not needed, the proposed method can be used for all PWM voltage measurements. The experimental results of voltage measurements are provided, the feasibility of the proposed method is validated, and the blanking time, the modulation ratio and the fundamental frequency are selected as three key parameters to evaluate the impact of parametric variation on the inverter disturbance.
Author Keywords: Dead-time;inverter disturbance;FPGA;PWM voltage measurement
IEEE Terms: Inverters;Voltage measurement;Pulse width modulation;Blanking;Field programmable gate arrays;Current measurement
INSPEC Controlled Terms: AC motors;field programmable gate arrays;PWM invertors;voltage measurement

Document Title: Calculation of magnetizing inductance and magnetizing current of squirrel cage induction motor
Authors: M. Matsushita; F. Ishibashi; S. Mizuno
Author Affiliations: TOSHIBA Corporation, 1 Toshiba-Cho, Fuchu-Shi, Tokyo 183-8511, Japan; Shibaura Institute of Technology, 3-7-5 Toyosu, Koto-ku, Tokyo 135-8548, Japan; TOSHIBA Corporation, 1 Toshiba-Cho, Fuchu-Shi, Tokyo 183-8511, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper describes a technique for calculating the magnetizing inductance and the magnetizing current of an induction motor with closed slots as a function of slip, using the magnetic energy and the magnetic co-energy. This method is based on the use of finite element method (FEM) analysis. And to calculate the magnetizing current from the phase difference between the stator and the rotor magnetomotive force (MMF), the two-dimensional (2-D) static FEM is also applied after the three-dimensional (3-D) nonlinear time-stepping FEM analysis. As a result, we can obtain the magnetizing inductance and the magnetizing current as a function of slip. The magnetizing inductance calculated from this method agrees well with the measurement result at the rated point of the motor. The method may be used for the calculation of the magnetizing inductance and the magnetizing current variation curves. It enables the motor characteristics to evaluate accurately in its design process.
Author Keywords: FEM;induction motor;magnetic energy and co-energy;magnetizing inductance
INSPEC Controlled Terms: finite element analysis;inductance;magnetisation;rotors;squirrel cage motors;stators

Authors: L. Zhiyong; W. Xuehuan; C. Linhong
Author Affiliations: College of Information Engineering, Xiang Tan University, Xiangtan, 411105, China; College of Information Engineering, Xiang Tan University, Xiangtan, 411105, China; College of Information Engineering, Xiang Tan University, Xiangtan, 411105, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: The increase of motor capacity cause the rise of motor internal temperature, the high temperature severely affected performance and reliable operation of motor. Considering influence of the permanent magnet eddy current loss on thermal field of motor, thermal field of PMSM has been analyzed by Lumped Parameter Thermal Network Method(LPTN), the thermal network model of 38 nodes has been established. Finally, the correctness of model is verified by comparison with the analysis results of Finite Element Method(FEM) and temperature test.

Abstract: In this study, the temperature characteristics of a one-stage and a two-stage structure of Peltier devices were measured. We identified that the two-stage structure was able to suppress the temperature rise at the endothermic end. A temperature difference was established based on the charge transfer in semiconductors, with respect to both Joule heating and thermal conductivity.

Document Title: Experimental verification of energy-saving effect of a single-drive bearingless motor
Authors: H. Sugimoto; I. Shimura; A. Chiba
Author Affiliations: Tokyo Institute of technology, 2-12-1, Ookayama, Meguro, Tokyo, Japan; Tokyo Institute of technology, 2-12-1, Ookayama, Meguro, Tokyo, Japan; Tokyo Institute of technology, 2-12-1, Ookayama, Meguro, Tokyo, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper presents energy-saving effect of a single-drive bearingless motor. In the single-drive bearingles motor, only axial direction is actively positioned. The other radial and tilting directions are passively stabilized by repulsive passive magnetic bearings. Therefore, it has advantages of low cost, non-contact, maintenance-free and long life-time. In this paper, an additional advantage of energy-saving effect is verified. In experiments, the input power is measured with and without mechanical ball bearings. The bearingless motor can reduce input power because a magnetic suspension power is low compared with a mechanical bearing loss. In addition, it is found that the efficiency can be improved.

Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: In general applications of inverters, it is necessary to boost the dc link voltage. As a result, the boost converter is generally installed in a first stage to implement such capability. This paper proposes a novel converter which unifies the boost chopper and inverter. By means of merely altering the connecting terminal of the inverter, the dc voltage of the corresponding inverter voltage can be boosted to double at maximum. In both of half bridge and full bridge circuit configurations, the method to give the double dc voltage is proposed and examined. In a final stage, another novel configuration is presented and discussed.

China; Danfoss (Tianjin) Ltd, No.5 Fuyuan Road Wuqing Development Area Tianjin 301700, P. R. China; Danfoss (Tianjin) Ltd, No.5 Fuyuan Road Wuqing Development Area Tianjin 301700, P. R. China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Design of PM-assisted synchronous reluctance motor (PMaSynRM) is usually used to enhance the performance of synchronous reluctance motor (SynRM). Permanent magnets are added into rotor flux barriers based on optimized synchronous reluctance motor rotor geometry. However, the level of saturation for the rotor magnetic path is different between a PMaSynRM and a SynRM due to these added magnets, thus PMaSynRM rotor geometry need to be re-optimized. In this paper, geometry optimization parameters of PMaSynRM with ferrite magnets are investigated to maximize average torque ampere ratio and minimize torque ripple using Finite-Element AnFinite-Element Analysisalysis (FEA). Finally, a prototype is built and tested to verify the investigation and comparison to simulation results are also given.

Abstract: This paper presents a method for estimating the electrical angle of the rotor for permanent-magnet synchronous motors (PMSMs) in model predictive current control (MPCC) so that an encoder is removed for high reliability and low system costs. Document Title: A sliding-mode robust controller for permanent magnet spherical actuator using neural networks
Authors: Y. Wen; G. Li; Q. Wang; X. Guo; S. Li
Author Affiliations: School of Electrical Engineering and Automation, Anhui University, Hefei, China; School of Electrical Engineering and Automation, Anhui University, Hefei, China; School of Electrical Engineering and Automation, Anhui University, Hefei, China; School of Electrical Engineering and Automation, Anhui University, Hefei, China; School of Electrical Engineering and Automation, Anhui University, Hefei, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: A novel robust sliding-mode controller using neural networks (NNs) is given for trajectory tracking control of permanent magnet spherical actuator (PMSA) with external disturbance and system model errors. The controller is established including sliding-mode scheme and the neural networks. The radial basis function (RBF) neural networks are chosen to approximate the unknown model and uncertainty, as well as to reduce the chattering of sliding-mode controller. The weighting coefficients of the neural networks are trained online. The robust control is employed to overcome the approximation errors from NNs. All the adaptive tuning laws for the NNs are derived from Lyapunov stability theorem. The stability of the closed-loop system, as well as the convergence of the position tracking errors to zero, is guaranteed by the proposed controller. Simulation results are provided to validate the effectiveness of the proposed controller.
Author Keywords: Neural networks;nonlinear control;permanent magnet spherical actuator;robust control

Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: With the augmented penetration of renewable energy, such as solar power and wind power, the electricity grids could be destabilizing due to the intermittent nature of renewable sources. In order to ensure power system reliability, robust optimization method is introduced to the energy schedule of micro grid system. This work presented a two-stage robust optimization method to calculate a numerical case of micro grid, with the uncertainty budget to control the conservativeness, and the value of uncertainty budget varies with the weather and time The column-and-constraint generation (C & CG) method is performed to solve the model using practical data sets. The analysis result of the numerical experiment shows that the method can solve the model quickly and effectively, that makes the system operation more reliable.

Document Title: Harmonic analysis for space-vector modulated grid-tied Quasi Z-source inverter
Authors: A. S. Nabih; A. Mahgoub; O. Mahgoub; Y. Ismail
Author Affiliations: Center of Nanoelectronics and Devices (CND), American University in Cairo/Zewail City of Science and Technology, Cairo, Egypt; Dept. of Electrical Power and Machines (EPM), Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt; Dept. of Electrical Power and Machines (EPM), Cairo University, Cairo, Egypt; Center of Nanoelectronics and Devices (CND), American University in Cairo/Zewail City of Science and Technology, Cairo, Egypt
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Current harmonics produced by power converters are strictly limited to ensure power quality in renewable energy integration systems. Quasi Z-source Inverter (qZSI) is used in such systems as a single stage Buck-Boost DC-AC converter. In this paper, the harmonic performance of space-vector modulated (SVM) three phase grid-tied qZSI is investigated. Traditional SVM and Modified-SVM schemes are analytically evaluated using double Fourier series technique. The current harmonic distortion is evaluated analytically using weighted total harmonic distortion factors. The variations in total and individual harmonic distortion levels versus the change in voltage gain are depicted. Simulation and experimental results at selected operation points are shown for a grid-tied qZSI to verify the analysis.
Author Keywords: Distributed generation;quasi Z-source inverter;space-vector modulation;power quality;harmonics

Document Title: Influence of freewheeling on single pulse operation of a switched reluctance generator
Authors: B. Burkhart; A. Klein-Hessling; S. A. Hafeez; R. W. De Doncker
Author Affiliations: Institute for Power Electronics and Electrical Drives, RWTH Aachen University, Jaegerstr. 17-19, 52066 Aachen, Germany; Institute for Power Electronics and Electrical Drives, RWTH Aachen University, Jaegerstr. 17-19, 52066 Aachen, Germany; Institute for Power Electronics and Electrical Drives, RWTH Aachen University, Jaegerstr. 17-19, 52066 Aachen, Germany; Institute for Power Electronics and Electrical Drives, RWTH Aachen University, Jaegerstr. 17-19, 52066 Aachen, Germany
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Switched reluctance generators (SRG) are a promising solution for back-up power generation for renewable energy or in electric vehicles. Classic approaches suggest choosing single pulse control angles to minimize dc-link rms current or excitation penalty to maximize system efficiency. Those publications only investigate the effect of turn-on angle θ<sub>on</sub>and turn-off angle θ<sub>off</sub>. The influence of an additional freewheeling period Δθ<sub>fw</sub>(U<sub>ph</sub>= 0 V) after the magnetization period Δθ<sub>mag</sub>(U<sub>ph</sub>= +U<sub>dc</sub>) is only investigated in more recent publications, coming to the conclusion, that efficiency can be improved. However, these papers leave out eddy current losses in the machine coils as well as losses in the power source. Consequently, in this paper the effect of such a freewheeling period after phase-magnetization on the system losses of a 20 kW 2-phase SRG (nominal speed 20krpm) over a wide speed range down to 1/3 of the nominal speed by means of system simulations is investigated. It will be shown that introduction of Δθ<sub>fw</sub>can lead to a more efficient use of the available co-energy loop and allows for optimization regarding different losses. A control strategy over a wide speed range will be derived from the analysis of the results.
INSPEC Controlled Terms: machine control;magnetisation;minimisation;reluctance generators
INSPEC Non-Controlled Terms: switched reluctance generator;SRG;back-up power generation;renewable energy;electric vehicles;single pulse control angles;dc-link rms current minimization;excitation penalty minimization;system efficiency maximization;turn-on angle;turn-off angle;freewheeling;phase-magnetization;2-phase SRG;coenergy loop;control strategy;power 20 kW

Abstract: The control system based on a sinusoidal tracking current controller and the primary flux linkage estimation on the stationary reference frame is proposed in interior permanent magnet synchronous motor (IPMSM). This control system is low-parameter sensitivity and it is superior to the disturbance suppression characteristics than a PI current controller. This paper constitutes a similar control system in induction motor (IM). In addition, this paper describes how to constitute in the IM of the control system which has been proposed in the IPMSM. Furthermore, the disturbance suppression characteristics of the sinusoidal tracking current controller shows to be superior to the PI current controller in the IM. Finally, the effectiveness of the proposed system is confirmed through the simulation results of speed acceleration and deceleration control and flux-weakening control. Moreover, this paper describes the differences of control structure and control performance between the IPMSM and the IM.

Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: The stator transient DC flux component emerges in the Double Fed Induction Generator (DFIG) following grid voltage dip, which results in an important influence on the controllability of rotor converter. In this paper, the research focuses on the responding time of the dynamic reactive current injection referring to DFIG with the crowbar protection under Zero Voltage Ride-Through (ZVRT). Firstly, theoretical analysis about the shortest quitting time of crowbar is carried out. Then, combined with crowbar protection and demagnetization control, ZVRT of DFIG is achieved as well as the fast injection of dynamic reactive current. Finally, the simulation results are presented to verify the theoretical analysis and the proposed control strategy. It is helpful to enhance fault ride through capability of DFIG.

Authors: Z. Yannan; L. Chuang; W. Kai; Z. Cong; G. Minjun

Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: In order to make further efforts to reduce the cost of switched reluctance drive which is designed for electric bicycle, a sampling scheme for single current sensor is proposed. Under the single current sensor sampling scheme, principle of unobservable area within the current ripple are analyzed. By establishing equivalent circuit model, the relationship between the maximum value of pulse current, the rise time of excitation current and the drop time of freewheeling current and other parameters are analyzed. Effect of motor winding resistance to pulse current amplitude, the rise time of excitation current and the fall time of freewheeling current is analyzed. The relationship between the winding resistance and average torque, torque ripple, system efficiency is researched. The optimization method is proposed to suppress the current ripple, by choosing appropriate winding resistance to adjust the excitation voltage and current voltage for changing the current rate to achieve the suppression of pulse phase currents. Finally, the sampling scheme and control algorithm of the switched reluctance motor are verified by experiments which show that this method is feasible and valuable.

Authors: Y. Ding; X. Xiao
Author Affiliations: State Key Lab of Security Control and Simulation of Power Systems and Large Scale Generation Equipment, Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, China; State Key Lab of Security Control and Simulation of Power Systems and Large Scale Generation Equipment, Department of Electrical Engineering, Tsinghua University, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper presents an adaptive sliding mode controller for the system of flexible load driven by motors with the damping and friction considered. The controller comprised the sliding mode controller and the Kalman estimator. Firstly, the parameter uncertainties and disturbance are modeled with a bounded variable and then an integral sliding surface is designed. Then, to relax the requirement for the bound of uncertainties, a Kalman state estimator is proposed to estimate the bound of uncertainties and the unmeasurable states. With the proposed control structure, the vibration caused by the flexibility can be suppressed and besides, the controller is robust to a wide range of parameter uncertainty and disturbance. The performance of the control strategy is verified via simulation and experimental results.

Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Energy behaviors are closely linked to the reliability of converters. However, there is not a scientific methodology to describe the energy characterization inside converters intuitionally. In this paper, energy flow in some basic units of converters is modeled based on the electromagnetic theory and the circuit theory. At this basis, a novel energy topology is investigated. Compared with the common circuit topology, its advantages lie in presenting spatial characterization of energy propagation and distribution. Furthermore, scientific visualization is applied to show the time characterization of energy flow. Last but not least, the energy propagation for operating converters is presented clearly in several case-studies.

Document Title: Two-phase induction motor drive improvement for PV water pumping system
Authors: E. Hayakwong; V. Kinnares; C. Bunlaksananusorn
Author Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, King Mongkut's Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Thailand; Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, King Mongkut's Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Thailand; Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, King Mongkut's Institute of Technology Ladkrabang, Thailand
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: In recent years, solar energy sources have been widely utilized, especially in PV water pumping system. Single-phase induction motors (SPIM) are the most common type of motor used in PV pumping application. Reliable operation, low cost and low maintenance are the main advantages of SPIM. However, SPIM have an inherent problem of low efficiency at low speeds, which can be overcome by the adoption of two-phase induction motors (TPIM). This paper proposes a new speed control method for the TPIM used in PV water pumping system. The TPIM is supplied with unbalanced two-phase voltages generated by the inverter that employs the carrier-based SVPWM switching strategy. The V/F control is incorporated to realize variable speed operation. The motor reference speed is set to be proportional to the power generated by the PV array. As a result, the motor speed always tracks power fluctuation of the PV array, leading to improved system efficiency. The validity of the proposed method is verified by simulation results.

Abstract: By incorporating the design concept of multiple excitations and stator-partitioned structure into the FSPM motor, a new hybrid excited stator-partitioned flux switching permanent magnet motor (HESP-FSPM) is proposed in this paper. On the one hand, by using hybrid permanent magnet (PM), the volume of rare-earth PMs in the proposed machine is reduced effectively with relatively high torque capability. On the other hand, the machine possesses a magnetic flux controllable capability due to the adoption of DC field windings. Finally, by using the finite element analysis (FEA) method, the electromagnetic performances are investigated in details, indicating that the proposed machines exhibit high power/torque density with less rare-earth PM and excellent flux-regulation capability.

Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Many applications are limited by the performance of the motors that power them. In the small power range, slotless BLDC motors are commonly used due to their intrinsic high power density and smooth torque characteristic. However, recent work has shown that the power density of radial flux rotating motors could be significantly increased by replacing their windings, made of copper wire by windings printed on flexible PCB, taking most advantage of the possibilities offered this technology. The aim of this work is to evaluate the performance gain that could be obtained by using this technology in linear tubular motors. To that end, an analytical model is implemented and used for comparing different winding shapes regarding to two criteria, one related to the power density, the other to the force smoothness. A track shape which annihilates the higher harmonics is developed and compared to different 3-segment PCB windings and to a conventional wire winding.
