Abstract: As the development of precise machining, electrical machines with high precision and high dynamic are the focus of research. This paper proposes three kinds of two-degree-of-freedom Voice Coil Motor (VCM), which provide linear-rotary motion. The VCM with two motion units has a great controllability and perfect rotary torque features, the one with parallel axes of motions has the highest average linear thrust, and the one with vertical axes of motions has the lowest thrust ripple and the highest average rotary torque. Structures of three VCMs are introduced firstly, and the magnetic circuits of three motors are analyzed. Then force features of three motors are calculated and compared by finite-element-method (FEM), and a prototype is machined and tested for performance verification. The paper provides the fundamental work for the two-degree-of-freedom VCMs, accomplishes the basic performance analyses.

Authors: D. Q. Guan; M. X. Bui; D. Xiao; M. F. Rahman
Author Affiliations: Energy Systems Research Group, University of New South Wales, Australia; Energy Systems Research Group, University of New South Wales, Australia; Energy Systems Research Group, University of New South Wales, Australia; Energy Systems Research Group, University of New South Wales, Australia
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper proposes a simplified Fundamental PWM Excitation (FPE) sensorless control method on IPMSMS direct torque control drives. This method is based on a five-segment PWM and the measurement of two active voltage vectors and one zero voltage vector during the first half of each PWM modulation cycle in order to obtain di/dts and estimate the rotor position therefrom. Compared to the conventional FPE, this method requires one fewer zero vectors for PWM pulse extension at high speed and high load. This reduces the current and flux ripples. The simulation results are shown to verify the effectiveness of the proposed FPE sensorless control and the performance comparison between proposed FPE and conventional FPE. Experiment results shows the accuracy of current derivative estimation under this simplified FPE method and compare the estimated rotor position with a shaft encoder.

Author Affiliations: Renewable Energy Research Centre, King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok (KMUTNB), Thailand; Renewable Energy Research Centre, King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok (KMUTNB), Thailand; Renewable Energy Research Centre, King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok (KMUTNB), Thailand; Renewable Energy Research Centre, King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok (KMUTNB), Thailand; Department of Mathematics, King Mongkut's University of Technology Thonburi, Bangkok, Thailand; Faculty of Electronics, Communications and Computers Science, University of Pitesti, Pitesti, Romania; School of Electronic, Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Birmingham, Birmingham, United Kingdom; Groupe de Recherche en Electrotechnique et Electronique de Nancy, Université de Lorraine, Lorraine, France; Groupe de Recherche en Electrotechnique et Electronique de Nancy, Université de Lorraine, Lorraine, France
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper presents an innovative control law for permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM) drive for high dynamics applications. This kind of system (three-phase inverter connected with a PMSM) exhibits nonlinear behavior. Classically, to control the speed and the current (torque), a linearized technique is often used to study the stability and to select the controller parameters at specific operating point. In this paper, a model based control based on the flatness property of the drive system is proposed. Flatness provides a convenient framework for meeting a number of performance specifications on the PMSM drive. To validate the proposed method, a prototype PMSM drive (1 kW, 3000 rpm) is realized in the laboratory. The proposed control law is implemented by digital estimation in a dSPACE 1104 controller card. Experimental results demonstrate that the nonlinear differential flatness-based control provides improved speed/current regulation relative to a classical linear PI vector control method.

Authors: N. Boonyapakdee; A. Sangswang; M. Konghirun
Author Affiliations: Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, King Mongkut's University of Technology Thonburi, Thailand; Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, King Mongkut's University of Technology Thonburi, Thailand; Department of Electrical Engineering, Faculty of Engineering, King Mongkut's University of Technology Thonburi, Thailand
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper proposes a new low voltage ride through (LVRT) strategy by utilizing extra resistance and inductance. Once voltage sag and low power demand occur simultaneously, the distributed generator (DG) is connected to low voltage (LV) grid through extra resistance and inductance. The active and reactive current injections are exploited to compensate voltage sag. Furthermore, the complication in the conventional method, caused by inserting inductance to feeder, can be avoided because the proposed LVRT strategy does not involve in utility assets. According to the simulation results, the voltage sag compensation of the proposed LVRT strategy is more effective than the conventional strategy which applies only inductance. This results in DG connected to LV grid longer.

Abstract: At load operation, suspension control of bearingless motors are became unstable by interference of the motor flux. Authors: B. Zhang; Y. Chen; S. Wang; X. Zhang; G. Feng
Author Affiliations: School of Electrical Engineering, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang 110870, China; School of Electrical Engineering, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang 110870, China; School of Electrical Engineering, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang 110870, China; School of Electrical Engineering, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang 110870, China; School of Electrical Engineering, Shenyang University of Technology, Shenyang 110870, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: In this investigation, a permanent magnet passively compensated pulsed alternator (PMPCPA) with ultra low mutual inductance has been designed to provide an electrical pulse with the large power for the load in the shorter period. The electric excitation is replaced by the permanent magnet excitation, the passively compensated mode is adopted, and two-phase symmetrical windings with an electric angle difference of 90 degrees are respectively placed in the stator slots with both deep and shallow specifications to reduce the mutual inductance between the windings. On the basis of design scheme, the inductance of armature winding of alternator is calculated. Both noumenon and short circuit discharge models for the PMPCPA are established to perform the simulation, and the mutual inductance of PMPCPA is measured. The simulated and experimental results show that the present alternator can meet the design requirements, and the effectiveness of method for reducing the mutual inductance is verified.

Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: In order to avoid effects of the variation of stator resistance and error caused by integral computation in the traditional speed-sensorless vector control, a reactive power-based sensorless control strategy for the five-phase induction motors(IM) with non-sinusoidal power supply is investigated. The proposed method uses instantaneous and steady-state reactive power value as the reference model and adjustable model to estimate speed. Both reference and adjustable model do not require stator resistance and flux estimation. This method improves the control accuracy and transient response performance of the five-phase motor system. Moreover, non-sinusoidal power supply technique is also adopted to improve the iron utilization and torque density of the five-phase IM system. The effectiveness of the proposed approach is confirmed by laboratory prototype experimentation using the dspace-1104 based controller.

Authors: F. Qi; I. Ralev; A. Stippich; R. W. De Doncker
Author Affiliations: Institute for Power Electronics and Electrical Drives, RWTH Aachen University, Jaegerstr. 17-19, 52066 Aachen, Germany; Institute for Power Electronics and Electrical Drives, RWTH Aachen University, Jaegerstr. 17-19, 52066 Aachen, Germany; Institute for Power Electronics and Electrical Drives, RWTH Aachen University, Jaegerstr. 17-19, 52066 Aachen, Germany; Institute for Power Electronics and Electrical Drives, RWTH Aachen University, Jaegerstr. 17-19, 52066 Aachen, Germany
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: An electric motor can be overloaded shortly to produce a much higher torque than the rated value due to its inherent large thermal capacitance. The state-of-the-art overload strategies are often based on the static characteristics of the motor. The real-time thermal condition is not taken into account, which leaves certain overload potential unused. This paper presents a model predictive overload control strategy for a water-cooled automotive switched reluctance motor. The maximum torque is calculated predictively based on an accurate thermal model with hot-spot temperature estimation. The thermal capacitance of the motor is fully exploited. Due to the predictive nature of the algorithm, the peak torque production is inherently guaranteed over the prediction horizon. The proposed method is experimentally validated. It allows frequent overload operations with up to three times of the rated torque on the test bench.

Abstract: This paper proposes a piecewise variable parameter model of iron losses in induction motors. In this model, two additional flux density terms are used to reflect the non-linear characteristics of the magnetic materials, and the main loss parameters of the proposed model are piecewise varying with the peak value and frequency of the flux density. Meanwhile, the fine analysis of the iron losses caused by fundamental and harmonic fields can also be carried out. Experiments are performed on a 5.5kW motors with different supply voltages, and the calculated results by the proposed model and Bertotti model are compared. It is shown that the iron losses predicted by the proposed model agree well with the test ones over a wide range of supply voltages.

Abstract: This paper proposed a model predictive control (MPC) method for open winding permanent magnet synchronous generator (OW-PMSG) fed by a three level neutral point clamped (3LNPC) converter and a diode rectifier. Authors: D. Liu; H. Polinder; A. B. Abrahamsen; X. Wang; J. A. Ferreira
Author Affiliations: Department of Electrical Sustainable Energy, Delft University of Technology, Netherlands; Department of Electrical Sustainable Energy, Delft University of Technology, Netherlands; DTU Wind Energy, Technical University of Denmark, Denmark; Department of Electrical Sustainable Energy, Delft University of Technology, Netherlands; Department of Electrical Sustainable Energy, Delft University of Technology, Netherlands
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Large offshore direct-drive wind turbines of 10-MW power levels are being extensively proposed and studied because of a reduced cost of energy. Conventional permanent magnet generators currently dominating the direct-drive wind turbine market are still under consideration for such large wind turbines. In the meantime, superconducting generators (SCSGs) have been of particular interest to become a significant competitor because of their compactness and light weight. This paper compares the performance indicators of these two direct-drive generator types in the same 10-MW wind turbine under the same design and optimization method. Such comparisons will be interesting and insightful for commercialization of superconducting generators and for development of future wind energy industry, although SCSGs are still far from a high technology readiness level. The results show that the SCSGs may not be too expensive regarding capital cost of energy. If other major costs and reliability factors related to superconductivity are taken into consideration, however, the SCSGs may not be competitive yet at the moment.

Abstract: In this paper, a basic design scheme of electric engineering maintenance rolling stock (EEMRS) is briefly described, which is composed of six power converters. In order to reduce the size of heatsink and increase the energy conservation and efficiency of power converters, the thermal resistance model of IGBT module and heatsink, and its thermal equivalent circuit are presented. A calculation method of losses in insulated gate bipolar transistor (IGBT) and freewheeling diode (FWD) in PWM inverter is given in detail, in which a new modulating function is introduced on the basis of space vector pulse width modulation (SVPWM) method. IGBT and FWD average losses expressions are deduced from the function. Moreover, a foster model is depicted considering the power devices junction temperature ripple. Finally, a calculation example is presented, the computational results are close to simulation. The results show that the junction temperature of FWD is higher than that of IGBT. It means that both of them in IGBT module must be taken into account when designing heat dissipation system.

Abstract: The phase currents of high-speed permanent magnet synchronous motor (high-speed PMSM) with sensorless control contain lots of harmonics. The closed-loop harmonic current detecting method is used to extract the fifth and seventh harmonic currents and voltage compensation is calculated according to the model. The analytical model of electromagnetic field produced by “8”word rectangular planar spiral coils is obtained from the second order vector potential formulation. The probe coil's inductance value calculated from analytical model and the value measured by bridge are compared. Abstract: This paper proposes an alternative approach to improve the dimensional accuracy of the holes manufactured with Fused Filament Fabrication desktop 3D printers. As opposed to the state of the art techniques, where they scale the input geometric designs according to their predictive and statistical models, the proposed method modifies the interior of the artifacts with respect to the geometric properties of them to compensate for the shrinkages of the holes. That is, the shrinkage itself is utilized to eliminate the effects of shrinkage on the holes. This is accomplished by interior line segments which simply pull the perimeters of the holes outwards so that the dimensional accuracy of the holes will be preserved. According to the measurements performed on a Coordinate Measuring Machine, there is an about 80% decrease in the dimensional error with respect to the conventional 3D printing.

Classically, to control the voltage and the current in the converter, a linearized technique is often used to study the stability and to select the controller parameters of the nonlinear converter. In this paper, a nonlinear-control algorithm based on the flatness property of the system is proposed. Abstract: Failures on a rolling bearing in the gearbox drive system can be detected via vibration sensors or accelerometers. Measured signals include rotating harmonics, noises, signals associated with a bearing fault. Characteristic frequencies of a faulty bearing are very close to the higher harmonics of rotor frequency. This causes a big challenge to know if a bearing is in a faulty or healthy condition by using spectral analysis. An effective extraction of fault-related signals from the measured signals is very useful to analyze the characteristic frequencies. It is found that active filters can fast extract the fault-related signals in the time-domain. The bearing diagnostic analysis can be quickly implemented on the extracted signals via Fast Fourier Transform in the frequency domain or energy calculation in the time domain.

Abstract: Control of a three-phase inverter with neutral-line voltage injection is proposed to improve the output voltage waveform. The main inverter converts almost all the input dc power to ac power in discontinuous rectangular waveform. The auxiliary inverter is applied to lower the output voltage total-harmonic-distortion (THD). Design of the proposed inverter is presented in the paper. Abstract: Phase locked loop(PLL) is one of the key techniques in the grid connection system of permanent-magnet synchronous motor(PMSM). Different types of the PLL are analyzed and compared. In order to overcome the traditional PLL shortcomings, an improved decoupled double synchronous reference frame software phase locked loop(DDSRF_SPLL) is proposed. This PLL is based on least error square filter(LES) and decoupled algorithm. And it is able to follow the grid frequency and phase angle more quickly and accurately. Besides, its anti-interference ability is strong, especially for low harmonics. The correctness and effectiveness of the improved DDSRF_SPLL is proved by the simulation on various conditions and experiment. The experiment platform consists of three level back-to-back converter and PMSM. This improved DDSRF_SPLL performs well in the grid connection system of PMSM.

Authors: P. Mungporn; P. Thounthong; S. Sikkabut; B. Yodwong; V. Chunkag; P. Kumam; N. Bizon; B. Nahid-Mobarakeh; S. Pierfederici
Author Affiliations: Renewable Energy Research Centre, King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok (KMUTNB), Thailand; Renewable Energy Research Centre, King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok (KMUTNB), Thailand; Renewable Energy Research Centre, King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok (KMUTNB), Thailand; Renewable Energy Research Centre, King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok (KMUTNB), Thailand; Department of Electrical Engineering, King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok, Bangkok Thailand; Department of Mathematics, King Mongkut's University of Technology Thonburi, Bangkok, Thailand; Faculty of Electronics, Communications and Computers Science, University of Pitesti, Pitesti, Romania; Groupe de Recherche en Electrotechnique et Electronique de Nancy, Université de Lorraine, Lorraine, France; Groupe de Recherche en Electrotechnique et Electronique de Nancy, Université de Lorraine, Lorraine, France
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper proposes a cascade voltage/current control method (vector control) for a three-phase inverter for grid connected applications. The study mainly focuses on the innovative control law based on the flatness properties for a three-phase inverter with output LC filter. Utilizing the flatness principle, we propose simple solutions to the control and stabilization problems. The effectiveness of the proposed controller is validated through experiments on a prototype 1-kVA testbed with a dSPACE 1104 controller platform. Finally, the comparative results for the proposed scheme and the conventional linear control (proportional-integral control) scheme are presented to demonstrate that the proposed algorithm achieves an excellent performance such as fast transient response.
Author Keywords: Flatness control;grid connection;inverter;pulse width modulation;vector control

Document Title: A new parameter adjustment procedure for the development of a ZVS double-sided LC compensated 4-coil wireless charging system
Authors: S. Wang; D. Gao; S. Chen
Author Affiliations: State Key Laboratory of Automotive Safety and Energy, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; State Key Laboratory of Automotive Safety and Energy, Tsinghua University, Beijing, China; University of Science and Technology Beijing, Beijing, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper focuses on the model analysis and parameter adjustment procedure of the 4-coil wireless charging system (WCS). Different models for the 4-coil WCS, distinguished by considering the nonadjacent-coil influence or not, are analyzed respectively. The LLC and CLC “T” compensation networks that are developed from the additional two coils in the 4-coil WCS are firstly proposed. An equivalent circuit model that takes the nonadjacent-coil influence into account has been analyzed in detail. And a practical parameter adjustment procedure, which could realize ZVS turn-on for MOSFETs and search for the optimum parameters, has been proposed. Finally, A WCS prototype with 87.7% efficiency from dc power source to load at 1.2 kW output power, 20cm wireless charging distance, is built up. Simulation and experimental results verify the effectiveness of the proposed parameter adjustment procedure.
Author Keywords: Wireless charging system (WCS);parameter adjustment;4-coil;wireless power transfer (WPT)

Document Title: Quasi-Z-source boost inverter with soft switching
Authors: K. Xia; Z. Li; Z. He; Y. Zeng; Y. Yuan
Author Affiliations: School of Optical-Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Shanghai for Science and Technology, Shanghai, China; School of Optical-Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Shanghai for Science and Technology, Shanghai, China; School of Optical-Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Shanghai for Science and Technology, Shanghai, China; School of Optical-Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Shanghai for Science and Technology, Shanghai, China; School of Optical-Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Shanghai for Science and Technology, Shanghai, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Traditional Boost inverters are limited by the range of output voltage, which overcame by Quasi-Z-Source Boost Inverter (qZSI). Quasi-Z-Source inverter has the capacity to acquire any expected output voltage at conduction ratio less than 0.5. This paper presents a novel topology that derived from classic quasi-Z-source inverter (qZSI) to get soft switching status for the main switch. The control method for the upgraded qZSI helped to realize zero voltage switch (ZVS) for both main and auxiliary switches. The relative theory and working principles are given. Simulations in MATLAB/Simulink circumstance and experiments in prototype are designed to prove the proposed new method. The results guarantee the practicability of the whole system.

Document Title: New high speed PMSM flux-weakening strategy
Authors: L. Sepulchre; M. Fadel; M. Pietrzak-David; G. Porte
Author Affiliations: Université de Toulouse; INPT, UPS; LAPLACE (Laboratoire Plasma et Conversion d'Energie), ENSEEIHT, 2 rue Charles Camichel, BP 7122, F-31071 Toulouse cedex 7, France; Université de Toulouse; INPT, UPS; LAPLACE (Laboratoire Plasma et Conversion d'Energie), ENSEEIHT, 2 rue Charles Camichel, BP 7122, F-31071 Toulouse cedex 7, France; Université de Toulouse; INPT, UPS; LAPLACE (Laboratoire Plasma et Conversion d'Energie), ENSEEIHT, 2 rue Charles Camichel, BP 7122, F-31071 Toulouse cedex 7, France; ACTIA Automotive, 5 rue Jorge Semprun, 31400 Toulouse, France
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: High speed permanent magnet synchronous motors (PMSM) are increasingly used in the field of electric traction due to their high mass and power density. Usually the motor is piloted by a vector control associated with a flux-weakening algorithm which regulates the voltage norm. If the critical point is located within the current limit then it is discerning at very high speed to drive the motor with a Maximum Torque Per Volt (MTPV) strategy. In this article we propose to achieve a unified control algorithm to drive the motor theoretically whatever its speed by giving a torque closest to its desired value while respecting the current and voltage limits and minimizing the current used. Consequently, at high speed at full flux-weakening MTPV strategy is applied which comes to modify the saturation of the current reference magnitude given by the torque reference associated with flux weakening strategy. It enables us to have no switch of algorithms, nor Look-Up-Tables (LUT) which are realized by experiments and depend on the motor, and to not introduce additional observers or regulators, while being precise and more robust to parameter variation than a direct calculation algorithm. The performance of this method is analyzed through a simulation.
Author Keywords: Flux Weakening;MTPV;Vector Control;High Speed PMSM
IEEE Terms: Torque;Voltage control;Traction motors;Permanent magnet motors;Trajectory;Synchronous motors;Table lookup
INSPEC Controlled Terms: electric current control;machine vector control;permanent magnet motors;synchronous motors;voltage control

Document Title: Design of high current low voltage half-bridges for multi-phase inverter application in the ISCAD drive
Authors: B. Rubey; D. Gerling
Author Affiliations: FEAAM GmbH, Werner-Heisenberg-Weg 39, 85577 Neubiberg, Germany; Universität der Bundeswehr München, Werner-Heisenberg-Weg 39, 85577 Neubiberg, Germany
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: A novel low voltage high power multi-phase inverter is presented. Based on an already designed ISCAD machine the specification of an electrical power up to 240 kW at a dc-link voltage below 60 V has to be achieved. For spreading the high currents and the corresponding power losses a 60 phase machine is built up. Each phase is connected with one dedicated half-Bridge, which includes power components and the driver circuit. The requirements on electrical circuits and components are investigated to ensure a safe operation of the system against voltage transients. Further simulations show the electrical and thermal behavior of the printed circuit boards. Experimental results validate the simulations and show the system boundaries.

Document Title: Study of parameter variations compensation in sensorless control of PMSM
Authors: S. Noguchi; H. Mabuchi; K. Suzuki; H. Dohmaeki
Author Affiliations: Motor Drive Laboratory, Tokyo City University, Japan; Motor Drive Laboratory, Tokyo City University, Japan; Motor Drive Laboratory, Tokyo City University, Japan; Motor Drive Laboratory, Tokyo City University, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Vector control is one of PMSM drive method, which used in many applications. But the vector control needs a position sensor, so it is desired the PMSM drive method without position sensor. However, in sensorless control of PMSM, control stability is affected by load variation and difference of motor parameters, so it becomes one of disadvantage of sensorless control method. In this paper, we use current estimation error method as a sensorless method, and use the on-line parameter identification as a compensation method of difference of motor parameters, examined the application and stability of compensation system by simulation and experiment.

Document Title: Direct power control for voltage source inverter without phase-locked loop under harmonically distorted voltage conditions
Authors: L. Li; H. Nian; P. Cheng
Author Affiliations: College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China; College of Electrical Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper proposes a direct power control (DPC) strategy for the grid-connected voltage source inverter (VSI) without phase-locked loop (PLL) under harmonically distorted voltage conditions. A virtual angular is employed instead of the voltage vector angular acquired by the PLL. The second-order vector integrator (SOVI) is integrated with the DPC to implement two different control targets of smooth active and reactive power or sinusoidal output current. Then, the different control performances of the SOVI and the second-order generalized integrator (SOGI) are discussed and compared. Finally, simulation results validate the effectiveness of the method.

Document Title: Simulation research of sensorless control of PMSM based on MRAS considering parameters variation and dead-time
Authors: J. Zhao; X. Zhang; C. Lin; G. Tian
Author Affiliations: Department of Automotive Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Automotive Safety and Energy, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China; Department of Automotive Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Automotive Safety and Energy, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China; Department of Automotive Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Automotive Safety and Energy, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China; Department of Automotive Engineering, State Key Laboratory of Automotive Safety and Energy, Tsinghua University, Beijing 100084, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper studies the senserless control of surface-mount permanent magnet synchronous motor (SPMSM) based on model reference adaptive system (MRAS) method. We focus attention on how parameter variation and dead-time influence the speed and position estimation error of the sensorless control strategy. Comparison of different impacts caused by each parameter variation is realized using Matlab/Simulink. The performance evaluation targets we choose are maximum speed/position errors, oscillation of speed error in steady state and position error in steady state. The simulation results show that the inaccuracy of flux linkage brings the most negative influence on the PMSM speed estimation. Second one is the q-axis inductance. The variations of d-axis inductance, resistance and dead-time have just little impacts that can be ignored.

Document Title: Current control method with enhanced PI controller for six-phase PM synchronous motor drive
Authors: L. Yuan; K. Wei; B. Hu; S. Chen
Author Affiliations: Institute of Communications Engineering, PLA University of Science and Technology, Nanjing, China; Institute of Communications Engineering, PLA University of Science and Technology, Nanjing, China; Institute of Communications Engineering, PLA University of Science and Technology, Nanjing, China; Institute of Communications Engineering, PLA University of Science and Technology, Nanjing, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: To suppress the undesired 5th and 7th stator harmonic current in the six-phase permanent magnet synchronous motor (PMSM), an improved vector control algorithm with enhanced PI controller was proposed based on vector space decomposition (VSD) transformation method, which can control the fundamental and harmonic sub-space separately. To obtain better control performance, an enhanced PI controller is proposed in this paper, which can achieve the zero steady-state error control of both dc and ac components. Moreover, the proposed method has taken into account the current unbalances in both x-y plane suppress the specific 5th and 7th harmonic component compensation, which avoid the need of additional complex control algorithms such as the synchronous reference frame transformation. Compared with the simulation results of existing methods, which verify the effectiveness of the proposed current vector de controller.

Document Title: Torque sharing and predictive current control of dual-winding bearingless switched reluctance motors for torque ripple reduction
Authors: C. Liu; X. Cao; R. Yuan; Z. Deng; J. Zhou
Author Affiliations: College of Automation Engineering, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, China; College of Automation Engineering, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, China; College of Automation Engineering, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, China; College of Automation Engineering, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, China; College of Automation Engineering, Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Conventional control strategies of the dual-winding bearingless switched reluctance motor (DWBSRM) produce large torque ripples due to the selections of the conducting phases and the waveforms of the reference currents. In order to solve the problem and realize good levitation performance at the same time, this paper proposes a novel control strategy which combines torque sharing method with predictive current control method. First, torque and levitation force commands are distributed among the three phases according to the rotor position. After that, the reference currents of the two sets of windings are calculated. Finally, a predictive current control algorithm is used to track the current commands by generating precise duty ratios applied to the two converters. The proposed method is verified by the simulation in MATLAB/Simulink in comparison with conventional control methods.

Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Provided with the reduction of the cogging torque by skewing slots and simultaneously the decent output performance, an analysis of a permanent magnet synchronous generator (PMSG) is proposed in this paper. Firstly, the best skewing angle with the lowest cogging torque is found and validated with the finite element method (FEM) software, ANSYS/Maxwell. To overcome the repellence of the cogging torque and back electromotive force (EMF), Taguchi methods and Grey theory are inserted in sequence for reaching the optimization of the multiple quality characteristics to satisfy our design goal.

Document Title: A study on harmonic reducing operation of double three-phase bridge capacitor-input-type diode rectifier
Authors: Y. Tsuboe; Y. Nishida
Author Affiliations: Power Electronics Laboratory, Chiba Institute of Technology; 2-17-1 Tsudanuma, Narashino, Chiba, 275-0016 Japan; Power Electronics Laboratory, Chiba Institute of Technology; 2-17-1 Tsudanuma, Narashino, Chiba, 275-0016 Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: The Capacitor-Input-Type 3-phase diode rectifiers offer several merits, e.g., compact size, light weight and cheap and thus, those are widely applied in practice. Though, their input currents distort significantly and it can cause harmonic pollution in power systems. Thus, it is essential to obtain solutions with maintaining the merits. In the Choke-Input-Type diode rectifiers, multiple three-phase bridge topology by means of phase-shifting isolation transformer has been well studied and widely applied in practice to mitigate input ac current distortion and output dc current ripples. Like them, the multiple three-phase bridge topology is applied in Capacitor-Input-Type diode rectifiers and it offers mitigation of ac input current distortions and dc output current ripples too. The effects are experienced through practice and known but not well studied nor explored theoretically. The authors have been engaged on study of harmonic reducing topology and the operating principle of three-phase diode rectifiers. In the studying process, it comes necessary to clarify the operating principle of the harmonic reducing double/multiple three-phase bridge topology of the Capacitor-Input-Type diode rectifiers. This paper is dealing with theoretical analysis of harmonic reducing nature in the Double Three-Phase Bridge Capacitor-Input-Type Diode Rectifiers. The validity of the theory has been confirmed through simulation studies.
Author Keywords: rectifier;harmonic reducing;capacitor-input-type;choke-input-type;multi-pulse;phase-shifting transformer

Authors: B. Yodwong; P. Thounthong; S. Sikkabut; P. Mungporn; C. Pukdeboon; K. Sitthithakerngkiet; P. Kumam; P. Tricoli; B. Nahid-Mobarakeh; S. Pierfederici
Author Affiliations: Renewable Energy Research Centre, King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok (KMUTNB), Thailand; Renewable Energy Research Centre, King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok (KMUTNB), Thailand; Renewable Energy Research Centre, King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok (KMUTNB), Thailand; Renewable Energy Research Centre, King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok (KMUTNB), Thailand; Department of Mathematics, King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok, Bangkok, Thailand; Department of Mathematics, King Mongkut's University of Technology North Bangkok, Bangkok, Thailand; Department of Mathematics, King Mongkut's University of Technology Thonburi, Bangkok, Thailand; School of Electronic, Electrical and Computer Engineering, University of Birmingham, Birmingham, United Kingdom; Groupe de Recherche en Electrotechnique et Electronique de Nancy, Université de Lorraine, Lorraine, France; Groupe de Recherche en Electrotechnique et Electronique de Nancy, Université de Lorraine, Lorraine, France
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Recently, the model based control has been successful applied for motion control applications. It improves better performance than a classic linear control. However, a model base control needs to know some parameters for exact estimations, here a load torque and stator resistance. In this paper, it presents three-observers for a differential flatness model based control approach for a DC permanent magnet motor drive. Observer I is based on the well-known Luenberger estimation (linear approach); Observer II is based on the non-linear approach which guarantees the asymptotical stability; and Obserser III is also based on the non-linear approach which guarantees the exponential stability. To validate the proposed methods, a prototype DC servomotor drive (GEC Alsthom: 2-kW, 2400 rpm) is realized in the laboratory. Simulation and experimental results demonstrate system performance.
Author Keywords: Flatness control;dc servomtor;Lyapunov function;pulse width modulation;speed control;observer

Document Title: Commissioning of modular 10kW magnetically levitated test rig
Authors: R. P. Jastrzebski; J. Vuojolainen; P. Jaatinen; T. Sillanpää; O. Pyrhönen
Author Affiliations: Lappeenranta University of Technology, Finland; Lappeenranta University of Technology, Finland; Lappeenranta University of Technology, Finland; Lappeenranta University of Technology, Finland; Lappeenranta University of Technology, Finland
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: In the complex rotor bearing systems all the components and control are interdependent. Changes in one non-modular element might require complete system redesign. Research on high-speed levitated blowers, pumps and compressors requires ability to test effectively different, often novel or customized, hardware and software components. This work introduces the laboratory test rig of modular construction especially designed to validate custom and novel components and control. The modularity imposes challenges related to accurate manufacturing, concentricity, positioning accuracy, leveling, mechanical robustness, and to commissioning and control retuning. We present the overview of reconfigurable test platform, which comprises different rotors and actuator modules. The commissioning, control and identification results of first configuration of this modular test rig are described. The experimental results validate the modularity concept, mechanical tolerances of manufactured modules. The model-based linear multi-input multi-output control is successfully tested.

Document Title: Extremum co-energy principle for analyzing AC current distribution in parallel-connected wires of high frequency power inductors
Authors: T. Shirakawa; G. Yamasaki; K. Umetani; E. Hiraki
Author Affiliations: Okayama University, 3-1-1 Tshushimanaka, Kita-ku, Okayama, Japan; Okayama University, 3-1-1 Tshushimanaka, Kita-ku, Okayama, Japan; Okayama University, 3-1-1 Tshushimanaka, Kita-ku, Okayama, Japan; Okayama University, 3-1-1 Tshushimanaka, Kita-ku, Okayama, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Inductor winding is often composed as parallel-connected wires to suppress the copper loss. However, in high frequency inductors, the proximity effect can cause concentrated AC current distribution, hindering suppression of the copper loss. Therefore, optimization of the physical inductor structure requires predicting the AC current distribution. Although simulators are commonly employed for predicting the AC current distribution, simple analytical methods are also required for effective design or invention of the inductor structure with less copper loss. The purpose of this paper is to propose a novel analysis method of the AC current distribution in parallel-connected wires of high frequency inductors. The proposed method is based on a novel insight that the AC current is distributed to give an extremum of the magnetic co-energy contributed by the AC flux and the AC current under the given total AC current. Experiments are presented in this paper to verify the proposed method.
Author Keywords: AC current distribution;Magnetic co-energy;Inductor;Magnetic circuit

Document Title: Simulated study of the multiple cascade Medium-Voltage inverter based on PSCAD/EMTDC
Authors: Q. Zhang; G. Lu; C. Zhang
Author Affiliations: SCHOOL of Electrical Engineering, Southeast University, China; SCHOOL of Electrical Engineering, Southeast University, China; Department of Electrical Engineering, College of Engineering, Nanjing Agricultural University, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: The number of unit's shaft ruptures caused by the transformation of the high-voltage inverter has been on the increase in recent years. It is necessary to conduct an in-depth study of causes and methods to control these accidents. In this paper, the author modeled the multiple cascade Medium-Voltage inverter based on the electromagnetic transient simulation software, PSCAD/EMTDC. Simulation results suggest that the output harmonic of the transformer of the structure is small, and its frequency modulation scope is wide. The single polar modulation has a lower harmonic distortion rate compared with the bipolar modulation. Simulation step size of a shorter time is required for the harmonic distortion analysis. The model and the modeling method can lay a solid foundation for the optimization research of the Medium-Voltage inverter control, fault mechanism analysis and fault inhibition method.

Document Title: Design and torque ripple reduction of the modular arc-linear flux-switching permanent-magnet motor
Authors: X. Liu; Z. Gu; J. Zhao; B. Li; X. Guan
Author Affiliations: School of Automation, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing, 100081, China; School of Automation, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing, 100081, China; School of Automation, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing, 100081, China; School of Automation, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing, 100081, China; School of Automation, Beijing Institute of Technology, Beijing, 100081, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Modular arc-linear flux-switching permanent-magnet motor (MAL-FSPM) used for scanning system is researched in this paper by the finite element method (FEM). The MAL-FSPM combines characteristics of the flux-switching permanent-magnet motor and linear motor. It can replace the reduction gearbox and kinematic mechanisms and can realize the direct drive and limited angular movement. Structure and torque characteristics of the MAL-FSPM are analyzed. Torque ripple is mainly caused by first and second harmonic of cogging torque during the whole operation. Based on the principle that torque ripple is reduced without decreasing the average torque, width of medium stator module and width of left and right non-magnetic material are optimized to reduce first harmonic of cogging torque, and the second harmonic of cogging torque is reduced by first harmonic current injection. After the optimization, torque ripple reduced by 72.43% and 45.65% for d<sub>end</sub>> τ<sub>p</sub>and τ<sub>p</sub>>d<sub>end</sub>>0° and average torque is approximately unchanged.
Author Keywords: First and second harmonic;harmonic current injection;modular arc-linear flux-switching permanent-magnet motor;torque ripple and average torque
INSPEC Controlled Terms: arcs (electric);finite element analysis;linear motors;permanent magnet motors;torque
INSPEC Non-Controlled Terms: torque ripple reduction;modular arc-linear flux-switching permanent magnet motor;MAL-FSPM;scanning system;finite element method;FEM;linear motor;gearbox reduction;kinematic mechanisms;cogging torque

Document Title: The active EMI filter for suppressing common-mode noise in bridge-less PFC converter system
Authors: N. Kikuchi; T. Hirono
Author Affiliations: Toyota Central R&D Laboratory, Nagakute, Aichi 480-1192, Japan; Toyota Industries Corporation, Ohbu, Aichi 474-8601, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper proposes an active electromagnetic interference (EMI) filter to suppress the common-mode voltage which is generated by a bridge-less power-factor-correction (PFC) converter. The active EMI filter topology is based on an active noise canceller of both the feedforward voltage detection and voltage injection methods. In this paper, the common-mode equivalent circuit model of the active noise canceller including a bridge-less PFC converter have been developed and the transfer function of an open-loop model based on the equivalent circuit model is derived in order to ensure the stability. The derived transfer function is useful in choosing the appropriate components value in order to achieve stability and noise attenuation performance in design of active EMI filter. Finaly, the proposed method has been analyzed theoretically and also verified in experiment.
Author Keywords: common mode active filter;power factor correction converter;electromagnetic interference;stability

Document Title: Research and design of high power factor induction motor drive based on V/f control
Authors: X. Wang; F. Wei; J. Yang; C. Luo; D. Lou; K. Yang
Author Affiliations: State Key Laboratory of Advanced Electromagnetic Engineering and Technology, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, 430074, R.P. China; State Key Laboratory of Advanced Electromagnetic Engineering and Technology, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, 430074, R.P. China; State Key Laboratory of Advanced Electromagnetic Engineering and Technology, Huazhong University of Science and Technology, Wuhan, 430074, R.P. China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper presented the design and implementation of an induction motor drive. In order to improve energy efficiency of this drive, system configuration comprised a single to three-phase converter with additional circuitry for PFC. In this design, using TI's UC3854 as the PFC controller chip, and the related parameters were designed. The control scheme was based on V/f control using two low-cost resistance current sensors. Only stator current measurements were needed to compensate for stator resistance drop. Regardless of changes in frequency or load, the magnitude of the stator flux can be constant by vectorially modifying the stator voltage. Furthermore, the hardware and software design were presented in detail. Experiments results showed that the proposed control system had high power factor and excellent performance.

Document Title: The design of LCC resonant converter for electron beam melting furnace power supply
Authors: Z. Haifeng; D. Ran; Z. Jinghua; L. Jianyong
Author Affiliations: Inverter Technologies Engineering Research Center of Beijing, North China University of Technology, Beijing, China; Inverter Technologies Engineering Research Center of Beijing, North China University of Technology, Beijing, China; Inverter Technologies Engineering Research Center of Beijing, North China University of Technology, Beijing, China; Beijing Institute of EDM Beijing, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: A high frequency power supply of the thyristors controlled rectifier and LCC Series Parallel Resonant Converter (LCC-SPRC)is presented on a variety of boost converter in this paper, which can overcome the limitation of the applications of LC Series Resonant Converter(LC-SRC) and LC Parallel Resonant Converter(LC-PRC) for high voltage and high power applications. The converter is used through the frequency control mode, and the equivalent mathematical model of the converter is given in Discontinuous Current Mode (DCM). The parameters of the resonant circuit are determined, and the soft switching of IGBTs can be achieved in much wide load range. The dynamic model of the system is established by using Matlab software. The Comparison of simulation and experimental results shows that the theoretical analysis of the design scheme is precise, and is feasible to use LCC-SPRC for high voltage power supply of Electron Beam Melting (EBM) furnace.

Document Title: Instantaneous voltage vector control and d-axis current reference calculation to improve source current waveform for an electrolytic capacitor-less single-phase to three-phase inverter
Authors: K. Abe; K. Ohishi; H. Haga; Y. Yokokura
Author Affiliations: Nagaoka University of Technology, Japan; Nagaoka University of Technology, Japan; Nagaoka University of Technology, Japan; Nagaoka University of Technology, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: In an electrolytic capacitor-less single-phase to three-phase inverter, a control bandwidth limitation adversely affects the source current response. Since the inverter does not energy buffer such as an electrolytic capacitor, the spatial harmonics of motor cause the source current harmonics. Moreover, d-axis current reference of the system is obtained by trial and error in off-line. This paper proposes an instantaneous voltage vector control that focuses the relationship of the voltage vector and the average DC-link current to improve the source current waveform. Moreover, d-axis current reference for the system is calculated on the basis of the analysis of the instantaneous voltage vector control. The effectiveness of the proposed method is verified by numerical simulation.
Author Keywords: electrolytic capacitor-less inverter;IPMSM;power factor correction;instantaneous voltage vector control

Document Title: A proposal for a new hybrid field motor with interpolar gap and permanent magnets
Authors: S. Kusase; K. Kurihara
Author Affiliations: Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Ibaraki University, 4-12-1, Nakanarusawa, Hitachi, 316-8511, Japan; Graduate School of Science and Engineering, Ibaraki University, 4-12-1, Nakanarusawa, Hitachi, 316-8511, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Recently, interior permanent magnet motors (IPMs) or motors with field winding have been investigated from a viewpoint of magnetic field control. The IPMs have an advantage of field weakening, however, its overall flux passing the stator core is not sufficiently suppressed. On the other hand, the motors with field winding can control more wide range, however, they need the field windings and are the complicated shape and heavy. In this paper, a new type of hybrid field motor without a field winding is proposed, whose rotor has regular salient poles arranged with interpolar gap and permanent magnet. And it is clarified that the interpolar gap and permanent magnet motor (IGPM) is more appropriate for field weakening control than the IPM from the basic equations related to flux and torque. We found that the proposed IGPM has yielded successful FEA simulation and experimental results.
Author Keywords: hybrid field motor;variable field;field winding;armature winding;bypass yoke core;IGPM

Document Title: Fast finite-settling-step flux linkage control with integrated active loss minimizing control of traction e-drive DC-to-DC converters
Authors: H. O. Yang; A. Koishi; R. D. Lorenz
Author Affiliations: WEMPEC Program, University of Wisconsin-Madison, USA; Power Electronics Development Division, Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan; WEMPEC Program, University of Wisconsin-Madison, USA
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: During the operation of a DC-to-DC converter in a vehicle, Volt-sec. is inherently embedded in a duty ratio and sourced to change inductor flux linkage, generating the output voltage trajectory compatible with the automotive e-drive command trajectory. With a flux linkage focus, the improved generalized Steinmetz equation (iGSE), i.e. the existing method for estimating core loss for nonsinusoidal waveforms, can be used with the loss model for the transient state of the output capacitor, such that the flux linkage and output voltage command trajectories providing minimum loss can be determined. Finite-settling-step (FSS) control for converters can quickly track flux linkage commands in two switching periods to provide fast command tracking on the output voltage commands, so it has the opportunity for active loss minimization. This paper implements the converter loss model into FSS control, to realize active loss minimization by manipulating flux linkage without compromising fast output voltage command tracking.
Author Keywords: Automotive;DC-to-DC converter;Finite-settling-step control;Loss minimization

Abstract: The paper presents a constrained optimization procedure to design a DC-DC converter with coupled inductors for minimizing the power losses. Document Title: A PV inverter with charge-pump circuit topology
Authors: H. Matsumoto; Y. Shibako; T. Matsumoto; Y. Shiihara; Y. Igawa; K. Okabe; R. Nagata; Y. Neba
Author Affiliations: Fukuoka University, 8-19-1, Nanakuma, Jonan-ku, Fukuoka, Japan; Fukuoka University, 8-19-1, Nanakuma, Jonan-ku, Fukuoka, Japan; Fukuoka University, 8-19-1, Nanakuma, Jonan-ku, Fukuoka, Japan; Fukuoka University, 8-19-1, Nanakuma, Jonan-ku, Fukuoka, Japan; Fukuoka University, 8-19-1, Nanakuma, Jonan-ku, Fukuoka, Japan; Fukuoka University, 8-19-1, Nanakuma, Jonan-ku, Fukuoka, Japan; Fukuoka University, 8-19-1, Nanakuma, Jonan-ku, Fukuoka, Japan; Fukuoka University, 8-19-1, Nanakuma, Jonan-ku, Fukuoka, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper proposes a photovoltaic (PV) inverter capable of stepping up voltage and the control algorithm for the inverter. The proposed inverter employs a charge-pump (CP) circuit instead of the commonly used step-up converter of a chopper type. Because the CP circuit does not include any inductor, the proposed inverter can be formed compactly. The CP circuit steps up the dc link voltage of the inverter by superimposing the voltage of the capacitor in the CP circuit on the PV voltage. So that the inverter performs the effective operation of the voltage step-up, the capacitor needs to maintain an appropriate voltage level. The equations modeling the energy variation of the capacitor are derived. Based on the equations, the maximum voltage step-up ratio of the inverter is obtained. The observation of the simulated output voltage waveforms of the inverter introduces two improved topologies of the CP circuit. The experiments using the inverter operated by the described control techniques confirms that the inverter can perform effective step-up operation while executing maximum power point tracking (MPPT) operation successfully.

Abstract: This paper presents the optimization of the performances of a controlled zero ripple input current high boost dc-dc converter with coupled inductors. Abstract: This paper describes an iterative method for rapidly solving the linear system arising in strongly coupled electromagnetic and circuit analysis problems. Document Title: A new technique for the skewing consideration in the 2-D FEM un-skewed induction motor time-dependant electromagnetic characteristics
Authors: K. N. Gyftakis; J. C. Kappatou
Author Affiliations: Coventry University, EC Building, Gulson Road, Coventry, CV12JH, UK; University of Patras, Electrical and Computer Engineering Dept., Rion, 26500, Greece
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: The skewing is the most commonly used technique for noise minimization in induction motors. In order to take the skewing into consideration in FEM simulations, one should design a multi-slice 2D model or a 3D model, since the skewing affects the motor design along the shaft axis. As a consequence, the complexity of the FE model increases as well as the computational time, especially when the analysis performed, takes into consideration the non-linearity of the iron core. This paper offers a technique for the skewing consideration in the induction motor, when simulated as un-skewed in transient electromagnetic 2D FEM analysis. The proposed technique could be particularly useful for faster simulations when the necessary simulation time is long, e.g. for diagnostic purposes. Experimental testing verifies the simulations' results with accuracy.
Author Keywords: Finite Element Method;Induction Motor;Skewing;Transient Analysis

Authors: Y. Zhu; K. Yang; D. Lou; T. Yu

Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This paper proposes a novel design of high power IGBT interlocking drive and protect circuit supplied by single power based on ACPL-332J chip. Firstly, it introduces the basic principle of interlocking drive circuit. Then, peripheral protect circuit is presented in detail, including chip protect circuit and IGBT protect circuit. Why and how to choose parameters of each component also are described. A novel interlocking drive circuit, without adding any components, is designed to prevent short circuit of DC bus when gate drive signals of the upper and lower IGBTs in the same phase are turned on at the same time. This IGBT interlocking drive and protect circuit is proved to be stable and reliable in Servo drive system of PMSM by experiment.

Document Title: Detection of pressure or flow rate variations in MR valves through magnetic flux analysis
Authors: G. Daniel; C. Yoan; P. Zoltan; P. Yves
Author Affiliations: Integrated Actuators Laboratory (LAI), Ecole Polytechnique Federale de Lausanne (EPFL), Neuchatel, Switzerland; Integrated Actuators Laboratory (LAI), Ecole Polytechnique Federale de Lausanne (EPFL), Neuchatel, Switzerland; MD, Service of Therapeutic Education for Chronic Diseases, WHO Collaborating Centre, Geneva University Hospitals, Geneva, Switzerland; Integrated Actuators Laboratory (LAI), Ecole Polytechnique Federale de Lausanne (EPFL), Neuchatel, Switzerland
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Magneto-Rheological (MR) fluids consist in a suspension of ferromagnetic particles dispersed in a fluid carrier. If excited by a magnetic source, the nearby magnetic field induces the particles magnetization with the formation of chain-like structures aligned parallel to the field direction. This phenomenon is responsible of the rise of a magnetic field dependent yield stress required to counteract the interactions between adjacent particles and break the ferromagnetic clusters. Thus, in the case of an external effort applied to the fluid, chain-like structures are stretched and the increased distance among adjacent particles results in an augmentation in the reluctance of the gap in which the MR fluid flows. The consequent variation in the magnetic flux produced by an exciting magnetic source can be detected as an induced voltage appearing in the system. The presented work proposes and discusses experimental sessions intended to underline the possibility to employ the aforementioned phenomenon in order to detect pressure or flow variation in MR valves.
IEEE Terms: Valves;Magnetomechanical effects;Voltage measurement;Magnetic flux;Magnetic domains;Magnetic resonance imaging;Saturation magnetization

Authors: G. Marsala; A. Ragusa

Abstract: The paper presents a real-time algorithm to compute the switching angles to control a three-phase multilevel cascaded inverter in order to minimize the THD to improve the EMC of the system. In particular, the proposed method uses an Artificial Neural network, trained by the GA algorithm, to identify the optimal switching angles corresponding to several values of DC sources voltage levels and the modulation index. Moreover, the algorithm searches the best sequence of switching angles to fire the different DC sources of the inverter to work in the condition of minimum Total Harmonic Distortion (THD). The method is validated by simulation results.

Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: This work addresses the design and the fabrication of small scale square planar coils with high density of turns and self inductances up to 170 μH. First, the modified Wheelers formula is used to determine the optimal number of turns in order to achieve the highest inductance. Then, an effective process flow based on polyimide (PI) and copper processing is presented, and the key aspects of the processing are discussed. Finally, the fabricated coils are characterized both electrically and morphologically, and the results are compared to the model showing good agreement with the theoretical calculations.

Authors: M. J. Guan; C. Liu; K. Wang; C. Zhou
Author Affiliations: Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, No.29 Jiangjun Road, Jiangning District, Nanjing, China; Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, No.29 Jiangjun Road, Jiangning District, Nanjing, China; Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, No.29 Jiangjun Road, Jiangning District, Nanjing, China; Nanjing University of Aeronautics and Astronautics, No.29 Jiangjun Road, Jiangning District, Nanjing, China
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: Compared with three-phase SRM, multi-phase SRM is higher power density and lower torque ripple. However, with phase number increasing, the requirement of power converters for multi-phase SRM such as using less power devices and independence between phases are enhanced. In this paper, six kinds of power converters for six-phase SRM are investigated and compared including asymmetric half bridge (AHB) converter and two derivative topologies; three power converter which have mid-point. Especially, a novel N+2 power converter is introduced in detail. Steady state performance and fault tolerance of six converters are compared respectively. Simulations based on the six-phase 24/20 SRM expose different characteristics of different converter. Fault tolerant experiment results of N+2 topology are also be interpreted in the last part.

Document Title: Consideration of current ripples inherent in a pulse width modulated voltage source inverter
Authors: T. Daido; Y. Hayashi
Author Affiliations: Aoyama Gakuin University, 5-10-1, Fuchinobe, Chuo-ku, Sagamihara-shi, Kanagawa 252-5258, Japan; Aoyama Gakuin University, 5-10-1, Fuchinobe, Chuo-ku, Sagamihara-shi, Kanagawa 252-5258, Japan
Publication Title: 2016 19th International Conference on Electrical Machines and Systems (ICEMS)
Abstract: The nonlinear characteristics of a voltage source inverter (VSI) with pulse width modulation is one of the biggest problem for sensorless ac motor drives because of both the output voltage error and the distortion of the output current. We have studied on the output voltage error of a VSI which mainly depends on the instantaneous current value at turning-off the self-commutating devices, such as IGBT. We have proposed the method to predict the instantaneous current at the turning-off by incorporating the reference values and the sampled values in the controller. We have verified the proposed method via a computer simulation which took only dead-time effect into consideration.
Author Keywords: Current prediction;Current ripple;Output voltage error;Pulse width modulation
